Title: As Retailers Spread Out Holiday Sales, Congested Parcel Networks Catch a Break
Option-trading opportunities on Adobe Systems, Alibaba, Micron, Netflix, and Tesla Motors
India’s Former Central Bank Chief on How to Fix the Country’s Economy
Text: Within emerging markets, India is seen as less vulnerable to the trade skirmishes playing out between the U.S. and China. That’s a positive, but the country is facing another set of challenges, from a deepening credit crunch and persistent bad debts at its public-sector banks, to a sizable fiscal deficit and an economy not growing as fast as it can.In our recent conversation with Raghuram Rajan, the former head of India’s central bank put some of India’s challenges in perspective—and offered ways to address them. Here are some more highlights of that discussion on India.India’s deficit put it in the “Fragile Five” group of countries deemed financially vulnerable back in 2013. Rajan helped get the country on a better course, in part by tackling inflation. The rupee weakened against the dollar to an all-time low this fall, and there are renewed jitters about India’s fiscal deficit.Rajan said some of the decline in the currency was natural as the rupee adjusted to the lower inflation rate. As for the deficit, Rajan says that India’s fiscal deficit has stayed around 7% of GDP, in part because an increase at the state level has offset reductions elsewhere. The country’s economic growth has kept a lid on the debt level, though Rajan says that is not something the country can rely on forever.India’s economic growth slowed to 7.1% in the second quarter—still among the fastest in the world but not fast enough. Rajan thinks the economy needs to grow at a pace of 9% to 10%, considering India needs to create one new million jobs a month. The easiest way to do that is to make it easier to build in India and increase the role of the construction industry through structural reforms, like making land acquisition easier—something that the federal government has grappled with for a while.“The reality is a number of states have figured out the secret sauce and the government needs to examine the experience and make it universal,” Rajan says. For example, the state of Uttar Pradesh came up with ways where it bought land from farmers by promising them some of it back after development.“The government getting involved in land acquisition is the third rail of Indian politics,” Rajan says. “As soon as the government pushes it in a big way, there are accusations it is favoring one group over the other. You have to find ways to assuage concerns and make it more transparent but also make sure India gets roads, highways and ports we absolutely need.”While at the Reserve Bank of India, Rajan tried to address the bad debt at the country’s public sector banks. But banks are still struggling with the issue. Part of the issue is that India didn’t have a bankruptcy court for years.For years, India and technology were synonymous. But there’s less talk about India in the new frontiers of technology, like robotics and artificial intelligence, which concerns Rajan. “There are start-ups that you may not have heard of but which are doing some interesting things, including [artificial intelligence],” Rajan says. “But they are at much smaller levels at this point than  Baidu,Alibaba, and  Tencent. The traditional IT giants will have to work very hard to have a presence in some of these frontier industries. Thus far, it seems to me it’s been slow.”India’s stocks have fallen sharply this year, and the  iShares MSCI India  ETF (INDA) is down about 8% this year. But in a note to clients last week, Gavekal Research strategists said they don’t see much potential for a bounce back more so than in other emerging markets. Despite the sell-off, Gavekal analysts noted that Indian equities are still trading at a 50% premium over emerging market peers—a large gap even if the economy is among the world’s fastest-growing.Write to Reshma Kapadia at reshma.kapadia@barrons.com

Title: China’s Beaten-Down Tech Stocks Could Be a Buy Now
Text: Chinese tech stocks have tumbled this year, dragging down China’s market and emerging equities more broadly. Those lower prices and a better outlook for 2019 could make this a good time to get into the shares, according to BlackRock’s chief equity strategist, Kate Moore.China’s tech sector has been hammered by worries about trade friction with the U.S. Regulatory changes in China also “imposed a drag on revenue for tech and media companies, many of which had grown unfettered and unregulated,” Moore writes in a blog.Chinese tech earnings surged by 56% in 2017. Yet profit estimates fell throughout 2018, with stock prices following, Moore notes.China’s tech sector is becoming a critical driver of China’s economic growth, supported by plenty of capital and favorable long-term policy from Beijing. “The Chinese are embracing technology to offset rising labor costs and the pressures of aging populations,” Moore writes. China aims to be more self-sufficient technologically, building its own semiconductor-manufacturing equipment and components, for instance, rather than importing as many goods.Read more: Trump and China Called a Truce in the Trade War. Now What?The upshot? The earnings outlook looks brighter for 2019, Moore writes, making this a good time for investors “to dip their toes into Chinese tech at more attractive levels.”Investors can get exposure to the sector through an exchange-traded fund. The iShares MSCI China ETF (ticker: MCHI) holds 36% of its assets in tech, almost entirely in three stocks: Alibaba Group (BABA), Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) and China Mobile (CHL).For more targeted exposure, the Invesco China Technology ETF (CQQQ) holds 74 stocks, including dozens of small and midsize companies involved in everything from mobile technology to e-commerce, gaming and semiconductor manufacturing. That makes for a more diversified mix, including many companies that don’t trade with American Depository Receipts, like Sunny Optical Technology Group (Hong Kong.2382) and NetDragon Websoft Holdings (Hong Kong.777).Stocks in the Invesco ETF have an average market capitalization of $14.4 billion and trade at a forward price/earnings ratio of 15. That doesn’t look expensive if Chinese companies can keep growing earnings in line with their long-term average of 21%, according to Morningstar.One consideration: Both ETFs are at the mercy of the trade war between the U.S. and China. Tech is at the heart of the dispute. China aims to develop a home-grown tech industry and maintain access to U.S. markets, while the U.S. is pressuring Beijing to stop the alleged theft of intellectual property and production of counterfeit goods in Chinese factories.Investors should hang on for a volatile ride. After surging 74% in 2017, the Invesco ETF is down 27% this year. Yes, Chinese tech stocks may look cheap. But they could get cheaper if the trade war worsens before getting better.Write to Daren Fonda at daren.fonda@barrons.com

Title: Chinese biotech stocks hit by a double whammy, which means it’s time to buy
Text: Have investors hit peak negativity on China-based companies? I think there’s a good chance they have. If so, it’s time to buy China stocks, especially in biotechnology.Chinese biotech stocks have been particularly hammered because they are getting hit by a double whammy. They’re down because investors are overly negative on China due to trade-war tensions. And unlike the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.09% the U.S. biotech sector is actually already in a bear market. The SPDR S&P Biotech exchange traded fund XBI, +3.65% was recently down 25% from its summer highs.I’ll tell you the best way to buy China biotech stocks — and it is surprisingly easy. But first let’s look at why the worries behind the selloff in China stocks and biotech in general are overblown.On China fears, it’s key to keep in mind that President Donald Trump’s negotiating style is to start with bluster (which spooks investors) and then dial back to compromise to be able to boast about a “deal.”That’s going to be the case with China trade. One reason is that, near term, neither country can stand — or deserves — the pain that comes from a harsh trade regime.U.S. companies have extensive supply chains winding through China, which will be hard and costly to replace. U.S. consumers enjoy the cheap, yet high-quality, goods that come out of China — everything from guitars to Apple AAPL, +3.49%  iPhones. China needs U.S. markets and access to U.S. business partnerships, and university slots for students.So we’re going to see signs of progress on China trade talks and probably soon — at the G20 summit in Buenos Aires Nov. 30 through Dec. 1.“The majority of clients believe there will be a truce, meaning there will be an agreement to resume negotiations and there will be no increase in tariffs over that period,” says John Normand, head of cross-asset fundamental strategy at J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +0.94%Even if we don’t get any signs of progress on China trade tensions, it never made sense that China biotech stocks should get hit by this war on trade. After all, who would hold human lives hostage to politics?On the biotech weakness, the key thing to remember here is that the selloff has little to do with sector trends, says Jefferies biotech analyst Michael Yee. It’s more about investors fleeing a high-beta group in a risk-off environment. When investor confidence returns, which is likely because there’s no looming recession and because the Fed will probably soon signal it’s reducing the number of planned rate hikes, high-beta groups like biotech will be among the best performers. China biotech stocks look like a great way to position for this kind of move, given the double whammy at work.But how to get access? Here you’re in luck. For the past few years biotech expert Brad Loncar has been travelling to China to meet with biotech companies and study which ones to put in a China biotech index he’s devised. Now there’s a an ETF based on that index. It’s called the Loncar China BioPharma ETF CHNA, +1.70%Loncar got a big break in this effort when Hong Kong recently loosened listing standards for companies, in that they’re no longer required to show revenue. This opened the door to listings of China biotech companies on the Hong Kong exchange. That’s a good thing for investors, because the Hong Kong exchange has fairly stringent listing standards. Mistakes will get through, but this generally means investors are less likely to buy into a fraud when they buy a Hong Kong-listed China biotech stock.The Loncar China BioPharma ETF gives you easy access to 28 biotech companies. Based on a small sampling of this group that I’ve studied and suggested in my stock newsletter, Brush Up on Stocks, these are quality companies with decent prospects. One of them is BeiGene BGNE, -1.64% which I first suggested in my letter at $28 in February 2016. It was up 685% by June 2018. And even in the biotech rout it is still up 400%. (My current buy limit is $100, give or take a little.) Another of mine in the Loncar ETF is the small-cap CASI Pharmaceuticals CASI, +5.31% This one advanced 270% after I suggested it in the low $2 range in early November 2017. I recently reiterated it because it looks attractive again in the pullback below $4.The Loncar China BioPharma ETF gives you access to plenty more potential China biotech winners like these, but it has one shortcoming, at least for now. Volume and liquidity are low, which means the bid-ask spread is wide. One way around this is to put in a limit buy order near the bid, and camp out until it gets hit.Besides an expected truce in the war on trade with China, which will soon put a bid under Chinese stocks again, here are four other reasons why it makes sense to invest in Chinese biotech for the long haul.1. The government really wants the sector to winUntil recently, China had no biotech or pharma sector speak of. Most pharma companies either developed generic drugs or manufactured drugs. “They didn’t do innovation or create new drugs, but that is changing dramatically overnight,” says Loncar. Biotech is a key part of the country’s efforts to spur continued growth by developing more sophisticated companies.2. The Hong Kong exchange now welcomes revenue-light businesses from China“That basically describes 99% of biotech companies,” Loncar, because they tend to be early-stage, developing businesses. The Hong Kong change is “huge” for China’s biotech sector, says Loncar, because it gives venture-capital firms an easier way to exit investments to realize gains, and put the money into start-ups. “That is super-important because it creates an ecosystem for investing in biotech for the first time,” says Loncar.3. China FDA upgradeChina has completely revamped its version of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), to bring it up to global standards, says Loncar. This improves the quality of the sector, and piques investor interest.4. U.S.-trained talent is returning homeMajor China companies including Tencent TCEHY, +3.44% Baidu BIDU, +1.62% and Alibaba BABA, +1.79% exist, in part, because Chinese nationals who studied in the U.S. and worked at U.S. companies like Google GOOG, +1.10%GOOGL, +0.60% Facebook FB, +0.34% and Amazon.com AMZN, +4.86% returned to China to work in tech start-ups.“A lot of Chinese professionals who were educated in the U.S. and worked at U.S. biotech companies are going home now and starting biotech companies,” says Loncar.Those four factors add up to a “perfect storm” that should create a solid biotech sector in the country over the next several years. If so, now is the time to buy in.Keep in mind that even if these stocks get a boost near term on signs of progress in U.S.-China trade talks, this group will be volatile because U.S.-China tensions will persist for decades as the two great powers battle for global hegemony.But there may be some good news in this, too. Persistent trade tensions could increase China’s focus on developing its biotech sector, as a way to move away from reliance on trade for growth, says Loncar. “They’re going to have world-class biotech sector, I have no doubt about that.”At the time of publication, Michael Brush had no positions in any stocks mentioned in this column. Brush has suggested BGNE and CASI in his stock newsletter, Brush Up on Stocks. Brush is a Manhattan-based financial writer who has covered business for the New York Times and The Economist Group, and he attended Columbia Business School in the Knight-Bagehot program.Want news about Asia delivered to your inbox? Subscribe to MarketWatch's free Asia Daily newsletter. Sign up here.Michael Brush is a Manhattan-based financial writer who publishes the stock newsletter Brush Up on Stocks. Brush has covered business for the New York Times and The Economist group. He attended Columbia Business School in the Knight-Bagehot program.Join the conversation

Title: Chinese Tech Stocks Will Always Become Victims of Their Success
Microsoft Stock Value Could Pass $1 Trillion in 2019
Text: Microsoft stock will rise in 2019 due to its soaring Azure cloud- computing business, according to Wedbush Securities.The firm’s analyst Daniel Ives reiterated his Outperform rating for Microsoft shares, citing Azure’s strong competitive position and growth potential.“Microsoft remains in an enviable position heading into 2019 on the heels of its cloud success and is firing on all cylinders around its Office 365 and Azure strategic vision based on our recent checks,” he wrote on Thursday. “Our expectation [is] that the company will cross the trillion dollar market cap during 2019 based on its cloud strategy and growth.”Microsoft (ticker: MSFT) stock was down 0.7% to $110.33 on Thursday. Ives reaffirmed his $140 price target for the company’s shares.Companies are shifting huge sums of their technology spending to the cloud as it offers better reliability, an easier path to scaling up, and greater cost efficiencies versus using traditional on-premises computing equipment.According to Gartner, Amazon.com’s (AMZN) Amazon Web Services was the leader in cloud computing with a 52% market share last year, followed by Microsoft at 13%, Alibaba Group Holding (BABA) at 5%, and Alphabet ’s (GOOGL) Google at 3%.The analyst noted that Microsoft’s Azure cloud business grew 76% in its most recent quarter. He estimated 30% of technology workloads are currently on the cloud, a share that he said will rise to 55% by 2022. Ives believes Microsoft’s cloud growth is in its early stages.“We believe the shift to cloud is a major secular trend that is significantly benefiting MSFT in the field as a key tailwind and should continue its momentum heading into FY2019,” he wrote.Microsoft has significantly outperformed the market this year. Its shares have risen about 30% year to date versus the S&P 500’s 2% return. The company has a market value of $853 billion, according to FactSet.Write to Tae Kim at tae.kim@barrons.com

Title: Option-trading opportunities on Adobe Systems, Alibaba, Micron, Netflix, and Tesla Motors
Utility stocks have beaten the S&P 500 in two months of turbulence and in the long run
Text: The S&P 500 utilities sector has been the best performer during the market decline that began in October. Don’t roll your eyes.We know it may not be a surprise, as utility companies offer investors a haven in times of turbulence. But what may interest you is how much better this stodgy sector’s performance has been over long periods.From the end of September, the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.09%  has declined 8%, including reinvested dividends, while the S&P 500 utilities sector returned a positive 3.3%. Here’s a chart showing how well the 12 sectors of the S&P 500 Index have fared over various periods:The S&P 500 utilities sector has been the best during the post-September market turmoil and has ranked second for 2018 through Nov. 26. But if you look at the longer periods, the total returns exceed those of the entire S&P 500 for all periods except for 10 years.But that 10-year figure is a bit deceptive. You need to consider what occurred before this 10-year period began. The S&P 500 was down 34% (including reinvested dividends) for two years through Nov. 26, 2008, while the utilities sector suffered a far milder 13% decline.The 20-year chart shows that, for the most part, the utilities sector has had less “downside capture” than the index:There’s no question that over the past five years, the information-technology sector, driven by the market-cap-weighted performance of the FAANG companies (Facebook FB, +0.34% Apple AAPL, +3.49% Amazon AMZN, +4.86% Netflix NFLX, +1.46%  and Alphabet GOOG, +1.10% ), has been the place to be. But the FAANG stocks have all fared even worse than the S&P 500 since the end of September, despite the companies’ fast growth.The 15-year and 20-year returns give evidence to the importance of the utilities sector: People and companies need those services in what is a critical industry protected by regulators. Utilities also reward investors with steady dividend payouts.Concentrating on individual stocks can be a risky endeavor. Shares of PG&E Corp. PCG, +2.77% the owner of Pacific Gas and Electric Co., are down 47% for 2018. Investors have worried that the company may be held liable for the California wildfires. Then again, some investors have looked at the decline as an opportunity.Regardless of how the PG&E saga plays out, there’s no question that a safer way for investors to gain exposure to the utilities sector is through an exchange traded fund, such as the Utilities Select Sector SPDR ETF  XLU, +1.01%  the Vanguard Utilities ETF  VPU, +0.86%   or the iShares U.S. Utilities ETF  IDU, +0.95%Here are all 29 stocks included in the S&P 500 utilities sector, ranked by how well they have performed over the past five years:You can click on the tickers for more about each company, including news, profiles, charts, ratings and financials.Don’t miss: These stocks are in bear territory, but analysts expect them to roar backCreate an email alert for Philip van Doorn’s Deep Dive columns here.Philip van Doorn covers various investment and industry topics. He has previously worked as a senior analyst at TheStreet.com. He also has experience in community banking and as a credit analyst at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.Join the conversation

Title: Why Tech Could Shakeup the $8.1 Trillion Global Logistics Industry
This chart shows a good sign for tech stocks, but the bear is ready to pounce
Text: After President Trump’s tweet about a potential 10% tariff on iPhone imports from China, investors’ heightened attention to technology stocks moved a notch higher.Becky Quick of CNBC was in tune with investor concerns, as shown in this segment, but it was my answer to the spot-on question from Andrew Ross Sorkin on tech stocks that has generated the most emails. At a time when gurus’ calls are on both bullish and bearish sides, many investors found some clarity in “Here’s how to tell if stocks will enter a bear market or rise to new highs.”Important events are ahead. Let’s update the situation with the help of a chart.Please click here for an annotated chart of Nasdaq 100 ETF QQQ, +1.75% I chose the chart of this ETF over the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.13% the S&P 500 ETF SPY, +1.32% and the small-cap ETF IWM, +0.96% because of dominance of tech stocks in the Nasdaq 100. The four largest components in the Nasdaq 100 are Apple AAPL, +3.49% Amazon AMZN, +4.86% Microsoft MSFT, +1.08% and Google GOOG, +1.10%GOOGL, +0.60% Please note the following:• The chart shows a move above the trend line. This is positive.• The chart shows a very short-term bottoming pattern. This is positive.• The chart shows RSI (relative strength index) divergence. In plain English, this means that although the price fell below a prior low, RSI did not go as low. This is a mild positive.• As the chart shows, the overall pattern of RSI is positive.• The low came on somewhat heavier volume. This is mildly positive. However, this is a low conviction point; a significantly higher volume would have increased the probability of this being a bottom.• As the chart shows, the rally is on low volume. This is negative.• Positive earnings from Salesforce CRM, +0.97% and Nutanix NTNX, +0.56% are creating positive sentiment.• Smart-money flows in semiconductor stocks such as Applied Materials AMAT, +2.84% and Micron Technology MU, +3.81%  have turned to neutral from negative. Smart-money flows have been positive in Intel INTC, +1.66% through most of the tech decline; interestingly, Intel has held up well during this period. Smart-money flows turned positive in AMD AMD, +11.31% at the depth of the selloff. You already know from my writings over the years that smart-money flows have a great track record. The cherry on top is that smart-money flows were negative in Nvidia NVDA, +4.04% when the stock was trading around $290, momo (momentum) crowd flows were positive and it was the darling of tech investors. Smart-money flows stayed consistently negative on Nvidia, and ultimately the stock fell to as low as $133. Please see “The poster child of bull-market excess just dimmed the prospects of the broader stock market” to see how money flows provide you with an edge.• For the medium term, the bear is ready to pounce on some high-flying tech stocks. Popular high-flying tech stocks can be cut by 50% or more from their highs, as explained here.Ask Arora: Nigam Arora answers your questions about investing in stocks, ETFs, bonds, gold and silver, oil and currencies. Have a question? Send it to Nigam Arora.There are times to have high conviction because the data support it. Over the years, you have seen my calls on stocks ranging from sell everything or hedge in 2007, to go aggressively short in 2008 and then back up the truck and buy in 2009. You have also seen my calls to sell gold at $1,904 an ounce and silver at $50 an ounce, both of which turned out to be the tops.The data do not support high conviction in the medium term at this time. In the short term, it all comes down to the Federal Reserve’s policy and the result of President Trump’s meeting with China’s President Xi, as described here.For market timing, I follow the ZYX Asset Allocation Model, which has inputs in 10 categories. Please click here to see the 10 categories.Disclosure: Subscribers to The Arora Report may have positions in the securities mentioned in this article or may take positions at any time. Nigam Arora is an investor, engineer and nuclear physicist by background who has founded two Inc. 500 fastest-growing companies. He is the founder of The Arora Report, which publishes four newsletters. Nigam can be reached at Nigam@TheAroraReport.com.Nigam Arora is an engineer, nuclear physicist, author, and entrepreneur and the founder of two Inc. 500 fastest growing companies. He is also the developer of the ZYX Change Method to profit from change by investing. The premise is that most money is made by predicting change before the crowd. Arora is the chief investment officer at The Arora Report and the editor of four newsletters that track the ZYX Change Method. Nigam can be reached at Nigam@TheAroraReport.comJoin the conversation

Title: Scott+Scott Attorneys at Law LLP Investigating Google's Directors and Officers for Breach of Fiduciary Duty Regarding Sexual Misconduct - GOOGL
Feds charge 8 people in fraudulent online-ad scheme
Text: The Justice Department charged eight people, most of them in Eastern Europe, with operating two alleged advertising schemes involving scores of faked websites and infected computers across the world, costing advertisers tens of millions of dollars.In an indictment unsealed Tuesday in New York’s Eastern District, prosecutors said the alleged schemes had been going on since at least 2014.Law enforcement conducted coordinated raids across Europe to take out the networks, followed by successive takedowns of the fake websites. Three of the eight alleged perpetrators were arrested overseas on charges including wire fraud, computer intrusion and money laundering. The others remain at large.“The defendants in this case used sophisticated computer programming and infrastructure around the world to exploit the digital advertising industry through fraud,” said Richard Donoghue, the U.S. Attorney for the district. One of the operations, named 3ve, was first identified last year by Google, a unit of Alphabet Inc.  GOOGL, +0.60%GOOG, +1.10%   , which lost millions of dollars in the scam, and ad-fraud-detection firm White Ops. Both companies said they turned their findings over to law enforcement.An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com.Also popular on WSJ.com:The U.S. housing boom is coming to an end, starting in Dallas.Transcript of President Trump’s interview with the Wall Street Journal.Join the conversation

Title: Google accused of breaking EU privacy rules, as Facebook comes under fire in U.K.
Text: Consumer advocates from four European countries filed complaints against Alphabet Inc.’s GOOGL, +0.60%GOOG, +1.10%   Google, alleging the company violating the European Union’s new data-privacy law in how it tracks users’ locations.The groups from the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Slovenia referred Google to their national authorities for what the groups say are breaches of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation. GDPR, which took effect in May, strictly delineates how companies may collect or process information about EU residents.The consumer groups said the search-engine giant collects location data on users of its apps through features and “does not give them straightforward information about what this effectively entails,” according to a statement issued by the European Consumer Organization, an umbrella group for national bodies across the continent. The groups say the practice violates “fundamental GDPR principles.”Separately in London, parliament members from an international committee representing nine countries questioned — at times angrily — Richard Allan, Facebook Inc.’s FB, +0.34%   vice president of policy solutions, about how the social network shares personal data and how it has fought misinformation. The company has apologized for what it said was inappropriate sharing of users’ data and a failure to move quickly enough to deter the circulation of fake news on its network. British parliament member Damian Collins said his office has obtained documents from a U.S. company, Six4Three LLC, that is separately suing Facebook, alleging its data policies were anticompetitive.Collins said one of the documents, which his office received last week, showed a Facebook engineer notified the company in October 2014 that an entity with a Russian internet-protocol address, via the image-sharing app Pinterest, had been harvesting information from the social network — much earlier than Facebook has previously said it knew about such harvesting.An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com.Also popular on WSJ.com:The U.S. housing boom is coming to an end, starting in Dallas.Transcript of President Trump’s interview with the Wall Street Journal.Want news about Europe delivered to your inbox? Title: Here are the best-performing U.S. stocks in Monday’s rally
Text: (Updated with market close information.)Whether you’re a fund manager or the president of the United States, a December stock rally is a wonderful thing. Many money managers have incentives tied to “locking in gains” before the end of the year, and of course President Trump wants all the bragging rights he can get.The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.13%  rose 288 points (1.1%) on Monday, while the S&P 500 SPX, +1.09%  also added 1.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.51%  was up 1.5% after Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to get serious about trade negotiations. Following a dinner Saturday night in Buenos Aires during the G-20 gathering, the U.S. agreed not to impose 25% tariffs on $200 billion in annual imports from China in January. This opens a 90-day window for a trade agreement.Read: Asia-Pacific stocks jump on U.S.-China trade truceTrump also said China had agreed to “reduce and remove tariffs on cars coming into China from the U.S.”Stocks were also helped by a 4.2% increase in West Texas Intermediate crude CLF9, +0.91% following an agreement between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman to cut production.Among the 30 components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, all but eight were up on Monday:You can click the tickers for more on each company, including news, profiles, price ratios, ratings and financials.Here are the 10 best-performing S&P 500 stocks on Monday:And here are the 10 best performers among the Nasdaq 100    NDX, +1.63%   :Don’t miss: Utility stocks have beaten the S&P 500 in two months of turbulence and in the long runCreate an email alert for Philip van Doorn’s Deep Dive columns here.Want news about Asia delivered to your inbox? Title: It’s Time to Get Choosy About Retail Stocks, Analyst Says
Text: Retail is off to a strong start this holiday season, but 2019 may not look so jolly.Where we were: Retail rallied for much of this year, and a strong Black Friday showing helped to alleviate some fears.Where we’re headed: It’s time to get selective among retail stocks as the backdrop becomes less accommodating, says Guggenheim.Before Thanksgiving, investors were worried that retailers wouldn’t be able to live up to expectations after a robust 2017 holiday shopping season. A strong Black Friday/Cyber Monday showing provided some relief, and then the sector got another boost from the trade truce, which at least removes the specter of a new round of tariffs for Jan. 1.While those factors may have put some skeptics at ease, Guggenheim’s John Heinbockel isn’t convinced. He argues that while retailers may be in a sweet spot now, the operating environment is basically as good as it can get, meaning that things are likely to get more challenging over the next year as demand drifts back toward more normal levels and cost pressures remain. That means it will be difficult for companies to keep improving margins and beating expectations for their earnings.It may seem odd to worry about retail at a time when consumer confidence is hovering around a nearly two-decade high, but Heinbockel writes that the robust readings from the last six months are simply too good to last. “This spending growth looks unsustainable,” he says.Not surprisingly consumer discretionary stocks have seen the biggest boost from consumer confidence. After all, it’s much more exciting to buy a new gadget or pair of shoes with the extra money in your pocket than it is to stock up on soap.Total discretionary spending has risen noticeably in the past two years, driven in large part by furniture, home furnishings, and information processing equipment. Yet that means these retailers could have more to lose. “In a moderating growth environment, discretionary would slow the most,” Heinbockel says.Then there’s the fact that e-commerce continues to grow relentlessly. While it’s no longer solely the domain of big players like Amazon.com (ticker: AMZN), traditional retailers that have a good online presence still often find that those sales come with slimmer margins, he writes. Freight costs are going up, as are wages, and while tariff relief is good, it’s only temporary.That’s not to say that Heinbockel suggests throwing in the towel, however. He writes that investors should stick with retailers that are “value-driven share gainers, in both discretionary and consumables channels, who should be able to deliver above-average, profitable growth in this environment.” Restoration Hardware parent RH (RH) and Performance Food Group (PFGC) are his favorite ideas, although he also likes At Home Group (HOME), Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Floor Décor (FND), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO), and U.S. Food Holdings (USFD).Heinbockel isn’t alone in his concern that the Goldilocks environment for retail can’t last forever. The stocks may be able to resume their rally through the end of 2018 if the holiday shopping season remains strong, but in the new year, tariffs will likely regain prominence in investors’ minds. Aside from that, the next catalyst for the stocks will likely be fourth-quarter reports, when we will get a better look at whether organic demand or deep discounting drove sales, not to mention how margins did in an environment where free and fast shipping is becoming the norm.The SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT) was up 1% to $46.80 this afternoon.Make the ConnectionDiscounters could be a safe haven as retail’s road gets harder.More thoughts on how long the retail party can last.Write to Teresa Rivas at teresa.rivas@barrons.com

Title: Here’s what would have made Virginia walk away from an Amazon HQ2 deal
Text: As the incentives for Amazon’s second headquarters attract attention, Virginia officials have been stressing they had limits on what they were willing to offer.The state’s team has promised about $800 million in direct incentives, including $550 million in cash grants if the e-commerce giant delivers on its promise of 25,000 new jobs over 12 years.“Had Amazon come back and said, ‘Well, no. We need that to be $1 billion to us, not $550 million,’ the state was very adamant that was not going to happen,” said Ryan Touhill, an Alexandria Economic Development Partnership official who was part of the Virginia team that worked with Amazon. “And we felt that was OK, if that was going to be the case. We could walk away from that deal.”His comments came during a panel discussion on Wednesday looking at government incentives in the wake of the competition among localities to attract Amazon.com Inc.’s AMZN, +4.86% secondary headquarters. When asked to elaborate on a walk-away number, Touhill said Friday that his point was that “if it got into the billions, like other states were offering, I don’t think we were going to go down that road.” Virginia’s Major Employment and Investment Commission, which approves such grants, had approved $550 million, and it would have had to sign off on any higher figure, said Touhill, who is chief of staff at the economic-development agency.Other officials from Virginia have made similar points. That state commission’s chairman, Frank Ruff, told the Washington Business Journal that Virginia was “not going to get into the bidding war.” The Virginia Economic Development Partnership’s director, Stephen Moret, has talked up being “a relatively low-incentive state” and wanting to win “in a Virginia way” that was “more about emphasizing our assets.”But Touhill pushed back this week when asked about whether any incentives were needed at all to land Amazon’s HQ2, given Northern Virginia’s strengths. The region’s positives include unemployment rates of about 2% in Arlington County and the city of Alexandria. Some locations that were finalists were offering “enormous” incentive packages, and Virginia officials felt “a need to compete” and make “a very prudent offer,” he said at the panel discussion in Washington, D.C., which was sponsored by the Pew Charitable Trusts and George Washington University’s Center for Washington Area Studies.Read more: What cities that lost out on Amazon’s HQ2 need to doTouhill also rejected suggestions that Amazon — whose CEO, Jeff Bezos, owns a mansion in Washington, D.C., as well as the Washington Post — had planned all along to pick the D.C. area. The Seattle-based company announced on Nov. 13 that it plans to locate its so-called HQ2 in both Crystal City, Va., and Long Island City, N.Y., with about 25,000 employees in each place, following a long selection process. Crystal City is in Arlington County, but neighboring Alexandria is due to become home to a new $1 billion Virginia Tech facility that was part of the state’s pitch to Amazon.“I don’t agree with the assessment that they had already decided before they started this,” Touhill said. “We went through 14 months of work and review on this, and there were moments where we felt there was still very stiff competition, and that it was on us to try to win it.”Economic-development deals in general have changed in recent years, and Virginia’s $550 million for Amazon is a performance-based grant, he said. “None of that money is going out the door until jobs are created. It’s not like the commonwealth wrote a check for $550 million at the signing ceremony.”Don’t miss: What every American should know about a Foxconn in their backyardVirginia’s offer has been praised as relatively restrained, with one local columnist even describing it as “stingy,” given that New York promised more than $1.5 billion in direct subsidies, while Maryland and New Jersey pledged billions in their failed bids to attract Amazon. On the other hand, New York officials have said the Empire State’s higher costs contributed to its offer’s being more generous. And a CNN report argued that New Yorkers could fare better because their minimum-wage laws will ensure decent pay for the thousands of new jobs that Amazon could indirectly create.Check out: Activists protest Amazon’s HQ2 in New YorkAnd see: HQ2 in the D.C. area could help Amazon snag a $10 billion Pentagon contractThe biggest misconception about developments in Virginia related to Amazon’s HQ2 is that “it’s all going to come tomorrow,” Touhill told MarketWatch. “This is going to roll out over 12 to 15 years.”Victor Reklaitis is MarketWatch's Money & Politics reporter and is based in Washington, D.C. Follow him on Twitter @VicRek.Join the conversation

Title: Code.org and Amazon Kick Off Hour of Code: Dance Party to Introduce One Million Girls to Coding
Roku Stock Stands to Gain From Pause in Trade Dispute
Text: This weekend’s U.S.-China trade truce could mean good tidings for shares of Roku (ticker: ROKU).The agreement, in which the U.S. will hold off on 25% tariffs on billions of dollars of Chinese goods, still leaves some business unfinished. But with the streaming-video company heavily reliant on Chinese manufacturing, DA Davidson analyst Tom Forte wrote Monday, one possible overhang on Roku shares could be removed—at least for a while.“The truce alleviates (but does not eliminate) a significant near-term risk to shares of Roku,” Forte wrote. “At current prices, we believe other risks, such as competition with Amazon.com (AMZN), are currently priced into [the] shares.”DA Davidson has a Buy rating and a $49 price target on Roku stock, more than 16% above current levels. The shares, down more than 20% in 2018 despite posting big gains earlier in the year, were up more than 4% to above $42 in Monday morning trading.Wall Street analysts remain bullish on Roku stock. The average price target is near $68, according to FactSet.Roku’s players—disclosure: Our household added one recently thanks to Black Friday pricing—are mainly made in China by Foxconn, then shipped to the U.S. and U.K., according to company filings. (Its speakers are made by another Chinese company, Tonly.)Roku’s revenue is spread between licensing, advertising and revenue- sharing with partners. As the company grows, device-related revenues should become a smaller percentage of total sales. In the third quarter, player revenues were 42% of the company’s total, down from more than half a year earlier. (Barron’s spoke with CFO Steve Louden in November after the company’s latest quarterly report.)“We are impressed by Roku’s leadership role in the emerging over-the-top video consumption market and are optimistic on its ability to exploit the $70 billion TV advertising spending market,” Forte wrote. We “believe the combination of the truce and where shares are currently trading provide an attractive buying opportunity for investors.”Email David Marino-Nachison at david.marino-nachison@barrons.com. Follow him at @marinonachison and follow Barron’s Next at @barronsnext.
