Title: Sell U.S. Tech Stocks, Buy Emerging Markets, Says Rob Arnott
Text: Investors may be thrilled that U.S. stocks have rallied, pushing the S&P 500 to a 4.4% total return for the year, including dividends, as of the close on Wednesday. But the good times probably won’t last, according to Rob Arnott, founder of the investment research firm Research Affiliates and co-manager of funds such as Pimco All Asset All Authority (ticker: PAUAX).A value-oriented contrarian, Arnott has long warned that U.S. stocks look pricey. And he’s especially concerned now that a handful of big tech stocks are carrying the market on their shoulders.“U.S. stocks have gotten frothy and expensive,” Arnott told Barron’s in an interview. “The FAANG stocks, in particular, are priced for perfection. If they don’t reinforce the notion that they’ll be 10 times as large a decade from now, then they’re overpriced and will perform badly.”The FAANGs refer to Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX), and Google’s parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Along with a few other big-tech stocks, including Microsoft (MSFT) and Chinese internet firms Alibaba Group Holding (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU), they have become a huge source of market concentration and power: Their total equity value tops $4.2 trillion, and they have been fueling the market’s gains.“The seven or eight largest companies on the planet are all tech darlings,” says Arnott. “Is that a diversified roster of top tier companies? Hardly.”Arnott points out that U.S. stocks trade at 30 times earnings, based on the cyclically adjusted price/earnings ratio (CAPE) from the last 10 years, a valuation measure developed by Nobel-winning economist Robert Shiller. The CAPE ratio only topped 30 once in history, just before the dot-com collapse, he says.Emerging markets, by contrast, look like a screaming buy. They trade at a CAPE ratio of 13. Investors worry that declining currencies and commodity prices will keep emerging markets depressed, and that the trade war between the U.S. and China will continue to be a drag on growth.But Arnott views those fears as overblown. “Will the trade war materially change the trajectory of half the world’s gross domestic product over the next 10 years?” he asks. “The answer is no.You cannot have a bargain in the absence of bad news that could get worse before it gets better. If you can accept that, then you have an opportunity to get some very good deals.”Granted, investors in Pimco All Asset All Authority haven’t seen great returns. The fund is down about 7% this year, and its 10-year annualized return of 5% trails 90% of mutual funds in the moderate-target-risk category, according to Morningstar.Arnott points out that most funds in the category are typically anchored to a 60/40 mix of stocks and bonds. All Authority aims to be different, holding what he calls “third-pillar” assets that can protect investors in a bear market and should do well in an inflationary environment: commodities, Treasury-inflation protected securities, and real-estate investment trusts. He also likes “stealth inflation fighters” such as emerging-market stocks and bonds, and high-yield U.S. junk bonds.Moreover, the fund is typically short the U.S. stock market, betting it will go down. “We actually have to love U.S. stocks in order to go above 0% in net U.S. stock exposure in All Authority,” he wrote in an email to Barron’s. Not surprisingly, he added, our returns “are in line with our home-base third pillar markets.”Those markets had an average return of 0.8% over the last five years. “That’s why our return lagged US stock-centric approaches—not because we’ve had an increasingly cautious view on U.S. equities,” he said.Still, it has been a painful slog for investors who have stuck with the fund while U.S. stocks have climbed, rising at a 14% annualized gain over the last decade, based on returns for the SPDR S&P 500 exchange-traded fund (SPY).“All Authority’s home base–away from mainstream stocks and bonds–will reliably lead to underperformance in a bull market,” Arnott tells Barron’s. “That’s what diversification does in a bull market.” At the end of what is now the longest bull market in history, he adds, “this is not a time to worry about the drag imposed by diversifying asset classes. “Indeed, Arnott sees a good chance that markets will start moving in his favor: He pegs the odds of a bear market breaking out in the U.S. in the near term at 40%. Investors might do well in a fund without much correlation to U.S. stocks in that scenario, though as he acknowledges, they may have to wait for their patience to be rewarded.“Do I have high confidence that the asset classes we focus on will beat U.S. stocks next year? No,” he says. “But I have high confidence they’ll win over a 10-year horizon.”Write to Daren Fonda at daren.fonda@barrons.com

Title: Hedge Funds Were Selling FAANG Stocks Before They Sank
Text: FAANG stocks have had one of their worst routs in recent months, with all of the them dipping into bear-market levels at some point–meaning share prices plunging 20% or more from the latest peak.Some hedge funds might have avoided part of that damage by selling the FAANGs early enough.In the third quarter, hedge funds sold over $34 billion in stocks–about 2% of their total assets, Jefferies strategist Steven DeSanctis writes in a Friday research report.It’s worth noting that the S&P 500 did not start dropping until Oct. 3; but hedge funds were already reducing weight in stocks throughout the third quarter in anticipation of higher risks and a trend change in the equity market.More noticeable was the sharp decline in their FAANG exposure. Hedge-fund managers reduced 14.6% of their FAANG holdings in the third quarter. Facebook (FB), whose shares are now 36.2% down from a July peak, saw hedge funds cut their holdings in the social network by 28%–a whopping $7.5 billion.Hedge funds were getting rid of FAANG stock before they slid. During the third quarter, while Facebook tumbled 16.7% and Netflix (NFLX) lost 6.0%, the other three FAANGs– Alphabet (GOOGL), Apple (AAPL), and Amazon.com (AMZN)–made gains. The FAANG stocks topped out at different times this summer, Barron’s noted.DeSanctis thinks hedge funds might be selling for another reason too: They were trying to raise more cash in preparation for next year’s redemption. Hedge-fund performance has been weak throughout 2018, even when compared with exchange-traded and mutual funds. Some managers might be anticipating more redemption from investors in 2019 and getting ready with their cash flow, writes DeSanctis.Whatever the reason, hedge funds’ shedding of FAANG stock has certainly contributed to the further turmoil for the group in October and November. In the fourth quarter so far through Thursday, all FAANGs were in negative territory, with losses ranging from 9.0% to 24.3%.“If this [hedge-fund] money comes back to the market, it potentially provides some fuel for a nice rally,” writes DeSanctis.Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

Title: Best Option Trade Ideas for Apple, Amazon.com, General Electric, Facebook, and Twitter
The Stock Market Keeps Forming a ‘Death Cross.’ What’s That?
Text: You’ve probably seen the word “death cross” a lot in the financial media lately. While the name itself sounds ominous enough, it’s important to understand what it is exactly, why people care about it—and why you shouldn’t panic when it happens.A death cross is a chart pattern that appears when a stock’s short-term moving average—meaning the average price over a certain time period—crosses below its long-term moving average. There is no fixed rule about what time frame to look at, but many define it as the crossover of the 50-day moving average and the 200-day moving average.A death cross is viewed by technical analysts as a signal that a major downturn is coming, as it suggests the short-term momentum in the underlying asset is slowing down enough and graduating into a long-term downtrend.To be sure, a death cross is usually not the earliest sign of a downtrend, but rather often confirms a pullback that’s been in place for a while. Investors concerned about bear markets often view the death cross as a timing signal to get out and lock in the gains before everything turns ugly. Hence, a death cross accompanied by high trading volume is considered especially significant, since that means people are starting to panic and sell.This year has seen no shortage of death crosses. A group of stocks, indexes, and asset classes have seen such a move. That incudes Facebook in April; gold in June; the Russell 2000on Nov. 13; Alphabeton Nov. 15; Netflix on Nov. 19; crude oil on Nov. 23; and the Nasdaq Composite on Nov. 26. Even the S&P 500came close to forming a death cross—twice.So does a death cross really bring about death? Not necessarily.First of all, a death cross is only so meaningful when both the short-term and long-term moving averages are declining. If the short-term line is falling but the long-term line is still going up, that’s not as concerning.Since 1928, the S&P 500 has experienced 12 “true” death crosses when both moving averages were going down, according to Bespoke Investment Group’s George Pearkes. The index declined 83% of the time in the month following those occurrences, with a median decline of 3.1%. But during the subsequent six months, stocks were actually positive 83% of the time, returning a median gain of 9.8%.“While a death cross doesn’t necessarily spell the death of secular gains for equities, they have historically been a relatively bad sign for near-term equity returns.” Pearkes wrote in a recent note.In fact, death crosses have become more common. Out of the 12 death crosses in the history of the S&P 500, four have occurred in this current bull market.“The fact that we haven’t seen a bear market following 4 separate instances of a death cross since 2010 is a good example of why ‘death’ might be a slight exaggeration!” Pearkes said.Indeed, investors who fled the market out of fear of the death cross missed sizable gains that came along later. Those who bought the dip gained handsomely in the following years.So a death cross might not be as fatal as it sounds. Instead, investors should treat it as just one of the alarming signs—among many others—they should watch for.Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

Title: There’s More Than One Way to Be a Value Investor
Text: During the market’s recent tumble, the outperformance of value stocks—the market’s cheapest—has led to talks about a revival of the out-of-favor group. But there’s more than one right way to be a value investor.In fact, there are many ways to measure whether a stock is cheap or not. Some of the most common metrics include price/earnings, price-to-book, and price-to-cash-flow ratios. The Russell 1000 Value index, the most widely watched value benchmark, uses price/book, while many prefer the ease of price/earnings.So which should an investor use? It depends on the sector, says Sara Shores, head of factor-based investment strategy at BlackRock. “If a U.S. technology stock is more expensive than a German bank, you wouldn’t expect it to be an apple-to-apple comparison,” she explains. “What is relevant is different by industry, [and] that certainly increases the complexity of the exercise.”Price-to-cash flow might be a good way to judge Boeing (ticker: BA), for example, but it isn’t really applicable to banks. The reason: The ratio captures only cash generated from business operations, while banks make most of their money from financing activities.And while price-to-book (or price-to-tangible book) works well for banks, it doesn’t work for companies with a lot of intangible assets like technology, patents, and brand reputation.“If you’re a car manufacturer, [and] you can well capture the valuation through property, land, and equipment, book-to-price might be great,” says Shores. “But if you are Facebook (FB), what does the book value of that company even mean?”So which metric should investors use? Morgan Stanley’s Brian Hayes and his team backtested 14 value metrics across 44 industries to see which offered the best returns and lowest volatility over the long run.When rebalanced once a year, cash-flow-related metrics were most effective in over 40% of the studied industries, including hotels, health-care providers, and household products. Despite its efficacy, however, among major value indexes in the U.S., only the MSCI USA Enhanced Value index included “enterprise value-to-cash flow from operations” in its methodology.“It’s not widely used probably because of the trickiness of applying it,” says Aye Soe, managing director of research and design at S&P Dow Jones Indices. Although cash-flow-driven strategies have earned a fairly good long-term premium in S&P Global’s research, they require a lot of nuanced decisions, Soe told Barron’s. Some complications include what to do when the cash flow is negative, or whether to use cash flow, free cash flow, or leveraged cash flow.Earnings-related metrics are the best measurement for about 30% of industries, including insurance and logistics. Price-to-book, despite being the cornerstone of value investing, is the top choice for only 7% of industries, including banks and telecom companies.The dynamic also changes depending on the time frame and how often a portfolio is rebalanced. Hayes’ research found that valuation metrics perform nearly as well at three-month rebalancing as they do at one-month rebalancing, but performance declines notably if the portfolio is only rebalanced annually.Finding the balance between a strategy’s effectiveness and its transaction cost can be key to the return difference. “For most industries, there is little motivation (once transaction costs are considered) to rebalance valuation-driven portfolios monthly,” recommends Hayes in the report.Most value-focused exchange-traded funds on the market don’t offer industry-specific stock selection, but for investors interested in getting their hands dirty, it might be worth the effort.Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

Title: Facebook Considered Charging for Access to User Data
Internal emails show Facebook considered selling user data
Text: Internal emails show Facebook Inc. considered charging companies for continued access to user data several years ago, a step that would have marked a dramatic shift away from the social-media giant’s policy of not selling that information, according to an unredacted court document viewed by The Wall Street Journal.The emails in the document also indicate that Facebook employees discussed pushing some advertisers to spend more in return for increased access to user information.Taken together, the internal emails show the company discussing how to monetize its user data in ways that are employed by some other tech firms but that Facebook  FB, +0.34%    has said it doesn’t do. At a congressional hearing in April, Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg said, “I can’t be clearer on this topic: We don’t sell data.”The emails — most from about 2012 to 2014 — are far from conclusive, lacking context and in some cases truncated. But they provide a window into mostly sealed court filings — which a British lawmaker has pledged to make public next week — from a lawsuit against Facebook filed by a company called Six4Three LLC. The emails also illustrate how Facebook has long grappled with how to maximize the value of the vast amounts of data it collects without abusing the privacy of users.An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com.Also popular on WSJ.com:Big Tech expands footprint in health care.Inside the Marriott-Starwood loyalty program turbulence.Join the conversation

Title: Facebook expands local-news feature to more than 400 U.S. cities
Text: Facebook Inc. said Wednesday it has expanded a local-news feature to more than 400 U.S. cities, as the social-media giant, which has struggled with everything from false news to data privacy, aims to keep users engaged on its platform.The company launched the feature, called Today In, earlier this year after surveys found that many users wanted to see more local news and community information on Facebook.Today In aggregates information such as road closures and weather reports in a specific section of the Facebook app, and users can get updates in their news feeds. The service also displays headlines from local publishers that have created Facebook pages.Facebook    FB, +0.34%     this year quickly expanded a test of the feature to 25 cities, including Macon, Ga., Charleston, W.Va., and Shreveport, La. It said Wednesday it has also been running tests with more than 100 city governments and first-responder agencies to help them alert residents to events like natural disasters.An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com.Also popular on WSJ.com:Big Tech expands footprint in health care.Inside the Marriott-Starwood loyalty program turbulence.Join the conversation

The company continues to grow its user base—it had some 2.3 billion users logging at least once a month in the latest quarter. And yet investors want nothing to with the company. Title: These 2 shocks will jolt stocks higher — and 15 smart ways to prepare for that move
Text: Investor sentiment has now fallen prey to the stock-market equivalent of cardiac arrest.That’s understandable. Popular stocks like Amazon.com AMZN, +4.86% Apple AAPL, +3.49%  and Facebook FB, +0.34% are all in bear-market territory. So are broad sector indexes like the Vanguard Energy exchange-traded fund VDE, +2.52% the SPDR S&P Biotech ETF XBI, +3.65%  and SPDR S&P Homebuilders ETF XHB, +1.58%Sentiment is now so dead that it suggests the next leg of the stock market is up, in the contrarian sense.Consider the ratio of open interest in puts (a negative bet) to calls (a more hopeful position). This ratio has spiked to levels frequently followed by rallies, says Doug Ramsey, chief investment officer of The Leuthold Group. “That would support my call for a possible bounce into year-end,” he says.Insiders, the people with the front-row seats on business confirm they expect the next major move is up. Insiders are bullish overall with purchases outweighing sales — an unusual tilt for them. They usually sell more stock than they buy.In analysis I do of insider activity for my stock newsletter Brush Up on Stocks, I’ve noticed that insiders are now particularly bullish in cyclical sectors like auto parts, home building and related retailers, real estate, chemicals and energy. This makes sense. Cyclical stocks are among those that have been hit the hardest. So they’re likely to rebound the most in a market reversal.Of course for markets to firm up again, something is going to have to jolt investor sentiment out of cardiac arrest and bring it back to life. Here are the two chest paddles that will soon provide the shocks that investor sentiment needs.Throughout this recovery since 2009 every time the Federal Reserve has started to pull away the comforter of low interest rates, investors have thrown a temper tantrum until the Fed backs off. That’s what investors are doing now, and expect the standard Fed response to soon happen again.This isn’t just about soothing spoiled stock investors. There are good reasons to be worried about the aggressive Fed rate hike path given many clear signs of a slowdown in the U.S. and throughout the world. Global purchasing managers indexes are rolling over. Leading economic indicators like home prices, automobile sales, oil prices and commodity prices are weakening.“We’re seeing swiftest deterioration in the global economic data in three years,” says Larry McDonald of The Bear Traps Report. “The trends in the U.S., Europe, Japan, and China are all pointing towards an upcoming global recession.”Bond markets confirm trouble ahead. The spread between yields on high-yield bonds and 10-year U.S. Treasurys TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.25% is widening.Read: Trump again lashes out at Powell, says he’s ‘not even a little bit happy’ about naming him Fed chiefThe upshot in all of this: “The U.S. equity market will crash in 1987 style if the Fed plays tough guy. It’s that simple,” says McDonald. He thinks U.S. stocks could fall another 40% in this scenario. This risk will make the Fed back away from its proposed course of aggressive rate hikes in 2019.“The Fed will have no choice but to pause on their policy path if they want to delay the end of the current economic expansion,” says McDonald. Central banks around the world will follow suit. We just saw signs of this in dovish comments from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi. “We see these comments as just the beginning of a wave of central bank talk that will shift dovish and move markets,” says McDonald.Read: Seemingly dovish, Powell says interest rates are ‘just below’ level where they won’t stimulate economyThe counter argument here is that it’s not the Fed’s job to manage the stock market. But this view is off target. At some point, the dramatic wealth destruction of a sharp market decline darkens outlooks so much that it reduces investment, which hurts growth. Investor fear also raises borrowing costs as it drives up bond yields. So calming investor fear to keep the expansion going is logically part of the Fed’s job. Besides, the stock market is one of the best leading economic indicators, so the big pullback is a negative signal on growth. Fix worries about growth, and stocks recover.Don’t be mislead by strong third-quarter growth. That’s history and the markets are forward-looking. Besides, it was an anomaly based on one-offs like inventory building ahead of trade tariffs as well as the impact of tax cuts and fiscal stimulus.Read: Economy grew 3.5% in third quarter, pushes corporate profits to 6-year high, GDP showsThe economies of both China and the U.S. are now suffering due to the war on trade. This puts pressure on both President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping to do something about it, and they will. “They’re staring down the barrel of an ugly global recession. President Trump and Xi know they must do a deal,” says McDonald.Yes, Trump just reiterated a desire to impose tariffs on Chinese goods. But McDonald views this as “hardball” ahead of the Group of 20 (G-20) summit this week in Argentina, where Trump and Xi will meet. Signs of progress here could boost U.S. stocks.Read: Here are 4 routes to defuse U.S.-China tensionsInsiders heavily favor cyclical names right now, and that’s one way to go. There’s recently been significant insider buying in homebuilding-related stocks like Meritage Homes    MTH, +0.71%   Home Depot    HD, +0.79%    and Lowe’s Cos    LOW, -0.08%   Insiders also favor cyclical names in energy, chemicals and the auto sector like Murphy Oil    MUR, +0.31%   Platform Specialty Products    PAH, +1.87%   and American Axle & Manufacturing    AXL, +1.20%While the S&P 500       SPX, +1.09%     and the Dow Jones Industrial Average       DJIA, +1.13%     will do well in any rebound ahead, McDonald likes Horizons DAX Germany       DAX, +1.67%      and iShares MSCI Europe Financials       EUFN, +1.47%      as plays on a rebound in European stocks, and XHB, SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production       XOP, +3.23%      and United States Oil Fund       USO, +5.03%     as cyclical plays in a rebound.He likes iShares China Large-Cap              FXI, +1.50%          and KraneShares CSI China Internet              KWEB, +3.19%           as plays on China stocks that will benefit, and iShares MSCI Emerging Markets              EEM, +2.02%          SPDR S&P Metals and Mining              XME, +2.76%           and VanEck Vectors Gold Miners              GDX, +1.83%           as plays on expected dollar weakness as the Fed backs away from its aggressive policy stance.At the time of publication, Michael Brush had no positions in any stocks mentioned in this column. Brush has suggested AMZN, FB, HD and LOW, in his stock newsletter Brush Up on Stocks. Brush is a Manhattan-based financial writer who has covered business for the New York Times and The Economist Group, and he attended Columbia Business School in the Knight-Bagehot program.Michael Brush is a Manhattan-based financial writer who publishes the stock newsletter Brush Up on Stocks. Brush has covered business for the New York Times and The Economist group. He attended Columbia Business School in the Knight-Bagehot program.Join the conversation

Title: These stocks are in bear territory, but analysts expect them to roar back
Text: In any market, at any time, there are stocks whose values are down significantly. But during a market correction, there will be more of those, and you may find opportunities to scoop up bargains for extra profits when the broader market rebounds.In mid-October, data provided by FactSet showed that exactly half of the stocks included in the S&P 500 Index were down at least 20% from their all-time highs. With the market pulling back since then, it might be interesting to use more recent data to see which ones have declined the most from their 52-week highs.A bear market for an index or an individual stock is usually defined as a 20%-plus decline. At about 11:10 a.m. ET on Nov. 26, 206 stocks among the S&P 500 were down at least 20% from their 52-week highs. That’s a huge list, but it might be of interest to see which of the companies in bear territory are favored the most among Wall Street analysts, whose research is used by their broker colleagues to help push stock purchases.The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.13%  fell 10% from its intraday high on Oct. 3 through its intraday low on Nov. 23. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.09%  was down 10.5% from its intraday high on Sept. 21 through its intraday low on Nov. 23. Both benchmark indices had suffered corrections earlier in 2018. The Dow ended on Nov. 23 down 1.8% for the year, while the S&P 500 was down 1.5%.The Dow was last in a bear market heading to the post-crisis low on March 9, 2009. But even though the financial media generally agree that the bull market has continued from that date, the S&P 500 on an intraday basis was in a bear market when it fell 20.2% from an intraday high on July 1, 2011, through its intraday low on Oct. 4, 2011, according to data supplied by FactSet.Starting with the 206 S&P 500 stocks in bear territory (from 52-week highs) through 11:10 a.m. ET on Nov. 26, we have narrowed the list to 22 companies that are covered by at least 10 analysts, with at least 80% of the analysts rating the shares a “buy” or equivalent, according to FactSet.Here they are, ranked by the percentage of buy ratings:Don’t miss: Here’s how to easily reduce your investment risk just at the right timeCreate an email alert for Philip van Doorn’s Deep Dive columns here.Philip van Doorn covers various investment and industry topics. He has previously worked as a senior analyst at TheStreet.com. He also has experience in community banking and as a credit analyst at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.Join the conversation

Title: Google accused of breaking EU privacy rules, as Facebook comes under fire in U.K.
Text: Consumer advocates from four European countries filed complaints against Alphabet Inc.’s GOOGL, +0.60%GOOG, +1.10%   Google, alleging the company violating the European Union’s new data-privacy law in how it tracks users’ locations.The groups from the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Slovenia referred Google to their national authorities for what the groups say are breaches of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation. GDPR, which took effect in May, strictly delineates how companies may collect or process information about EU residents.The consumer groups said the search-engine giant collects location data on users of its apps through features and “does not give them straightforward information about what this effectively entails,” according to a statement issued by the European Consumer Organization, an umbrella group for national bodies across the continent. The groups say the practice violates “fundamental GDPR principles.”Separately in London, parliament members from an international committee representing nine countries questioned — at times angrily — Richard Allan, Facebook Inc.’s FB, +0.34%   vice president of policy solutions, about how the social network shares personal data and how it has fought misinformation. The company has apologized for what it said was inappropriate sharing of users’ data and a failure to move quickly enough to deter the circulation of fake news on its network. British parliament member Damian Collins said his office has obtained documents from a U.S. company, Six4Three LLC, that is separately suing Facebook, alleging its data policies were anticompetitive.Collins said one of the documents, which his office received last week, showed a Facebook engineer notified the company in October 2014 that an entity with a Russian internet-protocol address, via the image-sharing app Pinterest, had been harvesting information from the social network — much earlier than Facebook has previously said it knew about such harvesting.An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com.Also popular on WSJ.com:The U.S. housing boom is coming to an end, starting in Dallas.Transcript of President Trump’s interview with the Wall Street Journal.Want news about Europe delivered to your inbox?
