Netflix Renews ‘Friends’ Rerun Deal
Relax, ‘Friends’ will still be there for you on Netflix for another year
Text: ”Friends” fans can relax, at least for now — the 1990s sitcom that’s inexplicably taken on new life with a new generation of viewers will remain on Netflix Inc. for another year.“’Friends’ will still be there for you in the US throughout 2019,” the streaming giant announced in a tweet late Monday.The Holiday Armadillo has granted your wish: “Friends” will still be there for you in the US throughout 2019 pic.twitter.com/Yd0VqRzk3rPanicked fans inundated Netflix NFLX, +1.46%   with emails and pleas on social media over the past couple of days after a notice popped up on the show’s Netflix page that said it would no longer be available after Jan. 1.Netflix is really removing Friends on January 1st and the only reason I have an account is to rewatch the same episodes of the show whenever I’m bored so I guess it’s time to cancel my subscriptionHey @netflix, this is for taking Friends off. Thanks for ruining everyone’s 2019. pic.twitter.com/SuUYudBEowTHE ONLY REASON I HAVE AN ACCOUNT WITH NETFLIX IS TO REWATCH FRIENDS. WHY @netflix ARE YOU HURTING US.“Friends” was produced by AT&T’s              T, +1.50%            Warner Bros., and it was assumed the show would leave Netflix when its contract expires at the end of the year, and find a new home when WarnerMedia launches its streaming service in late 2019.Neither Netflix nor WarnerMedia immediately explained the situation, but it’s likely Netflix was able to extend its streaming contact for another year. But “Friends” is still likely to jump to WarnerMedia at the beginning of 2020, once the service is up.Netflix bought the streaming rights to all 10 season of “Friends” in 2015, and it’s been a big hit with viewers — especially teens and millennials — since. The show also airs on WarnerMedia’s TBS and some Viacom Inc.                                                     VIA, +1.26%                                        cable channels.Join the conversation

Title: Netflix shrugs off hard-to-crack China market, sees more opportunity in India
Text: Netflix Inc. investors shouldn’t bet on a real presence in China anytime soon, but the company still sees major opportunities ahead in other international markets.Speaking at a UBS investment conference Monday, Netflix Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos downplayed the possibility that Netflix NFLX, +1.46%  would gain entry into the Chinese market in the near future, citing what he viewed as “very, very random” approaches to content approval in that country.“You can really spin up your wheels trying to get a lot of programming sold into China and then for no rhyme or reason, the show gets blocked or kicked out,” Sarandos said. While China might one day be more open to Western media companies, he told investors at the conference that “I don’t think that’s very likely” today.Don’t miss: Netflix, Warner Bros. and Satanic Temple reach ‘amicable’ settlementSarandos spoke about more feasible international efforts, including in India, where he said there was mostly a “very big movie culture” and that television was mainly “lower production value.” Netflix faces some challenges in India because so many languages are spoken there, but the company is currently working on a show called “Baahubali: Before the Beginning,” which is a prequel to a popular film franchise and will be shot in multiple languages.The company sees “amplified” benefits from word of mouth in India because of its huge population, Sarandos added. He said Netflix has about 12 local-language series in production in India, as well as 20 original films.See also: Netflix is gearing up to have a ‘meaningfully stronger’ content slate next year, says Credit SuisseAccording to Sarandos, the company is glad when local content takes off outside its intended country, but Netflix doesn’t set that as its goal for foreign-language programming. He mentioned “Dark,” a German-language original show that’s taken off in other countries.“If they focus on doing a global hit, there would be something artificial and manufactured about it that wouldn’t work,” Sarandos said. “So ‘Dark’ is an incredibly German show, it’s very local, and that’s what makes it work.”Read: It’s time to stop lumping Netflix in with the other FAANG stocks, says analystNetflix shares were up as much as 4.4% in Monday’s session, though they headed lower after Sarandos spoke. The stock ended up 1.5% on the day, and it’s gained 51% so far this year. The S&P 500              SPX, +1.09%           has risen 4.4% in that time.Want news about Asia delivered to your inbox? Subscribe to MarketWatch's free Asia Daily newsletter. Sign up here.Emily Bary is a MarketWatch reporter based in New York.Join the conversation

Title: Netflix, Rapped by SNL, Will Keep Spending on Content Anyway
Text: How fast does Netflix (NFLX) need to move to stay ahead of the competition in streaming video? Faster, it seems, than the writers at Saturday Night Live.SNL had some fun with the company’s multibillion-dollar programming strategy this weekend, running a mock commercial declaring that “In 2019, we’ll have even more programming to choose from because we’ve GONE CRAZY.”“We’re spending billions of dollars and making every show in the world,” the announcer said.Asked about the commercial during a UBS conference Monday, Netflix Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos pointed out that South Park did it first, with a company executive answering the phone “Netflix, you’re greenlit.””The challenge [for] SNL is they’ve got to be funnier—and faster—than those guys,” Sarandos said, after joking that he would happily buy SNL’s mock series Leslie Jones in a Van Getting Batteries.Sarandos offered less-jocular insights a bit later as he responded to a question about how the company measures return on its content spending:We look at the incremental investment in content. And we look at it and say, “Look, at some point, you’re going to hit a point of diminishing returns on the investment,” meaning that we’re putting new money in and not getting any new watching out. And I think until we see that, I think that we’re enthused to push forward, meaning that we will keep investing more in programming.But we’re also getting more users and more hours of usage from our existing users. So, meaning, there’s a lot more growth, we think, and [we] continue to invest in more programming today. When we see those kind of inflection points to the business where that's no longer the case, then we could start looking at that.And the marginal cost of being wrong about it, by the way, meaning overinvesting in it, is not that high. So what you don’t want to do is pull back too fast and figure out that you were wrong, where the other one is you over invest by one marginal show or one incremental show that you may or may not have needed. I think that’s probably the right trade-off in the business.Shares of Netflix closed Monday up about 1.5% at around $290, leaving them up about 51% in 2018 after falling more than 22% in Q4.This story has been updated since it was first published to reflect closing prices.Email David Marino-Nachison at david.marino-nachison@barrons.com. Follow him at @marinonachison and follow Barron’s Next at @barronsnext.

Title: Utility stocks have beaten the S&P 500 in two months of turbulence and in the long run
Text: The S&P 500 utilities sector has been the best performer during the market decline that began in October. Don’t roll your eyes.We know it may not be a surprise, as utility companies offer investors a haven in times of turbulence. But what may interest you is how much better this stodgy sector’s performance has been over long periods.From the end of September, the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.09%  has declined 8%, including reinvested dividends, while the S&P 500 utilities sector returned a positive 3.3%. Here’s a chart showing how well the 12 sectors of the S&P 500 Index have fared over various periods:The S&P 500 utilities sector has been the best during the post-September market turmoil and has ranked second for 2018 through Nov. 26. But if you look at the longer periods, the total returns exceed those of the entire S&P 500 for all periods except for 10 years.But that 10-year figure is a bit deceptive. You need to consider what occurred before this 10-year period began. The S&P 500 was down 34% (including reinvested dividends) for two years through Nov. 26, 2008, while the utilities sector suffered a far milder 13% decline.The 20-year chart shows that, for the most part, the utilities sector has had less “downside capture” than the index:There’s no question that over the past five years, the information-technology sector, driven by the market-cap-weighted performance of the FAANG companies (Facebook FB, +0.34% Apple AAPL, +3.49% Amazon AMZN, +4.86% Netflix NFLX, +1.46%  and Alphabet GOOG, +1.10% ), has been the place to be. But the FAANG stocks have all fared even worse than the S&P 500 since the end of September, despite the companies’ fast growth.The 15-year and 20-year returns give evidence to the importance of the utilities sector: People and companies need those services in what is a critical industry protected by regulators. Utilities also reward investors with steady dividend payouts.Concentrating on individual stocks can be a risky endeavor. Shares of PG&E Corp. PCG, +2.77% the owner of Pacific Gas and Electric Co., are down 47% for 2018. Investors have worried that the company may be held liable for the California wildfires. Then again, some investors have looked at the decline as an opportunity.Regardless of how the PG&E saga plays out, there’s no question that a safer way for investors to gain exposure to the utilities sector is through an exchange traded fund, such as the Utilities Select Sector SPDR ETF  XLU, +1.01%  the Vanguard Utilities ETF  VPU, +0.86%   or the iShares U.S. Utilities ETF  IDU, +0.95%Here are all 29 stocks included in the S&P 500 utilities sector, ranked by how well they have performed over the past five years:You can click on the tickers for more about each company, including news, profiles, charts, ratings and financials.Don’t miss: These stocks are in bear territory, but analysts expect them to roar backCreate an email alert for Philip van Doorn’s Deep Dive columns here.Philip van Doorn covers various investment and industry topics. He has previously worked as a senior analyst at TheStreet.com. He also has experience in community banking and as a credit analyst at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.Join the conversation

Title: Sell U.S. Tech Stocks, Buy Emerging Markets, Says Rob Arnott
Text: Investors may be thrilled that U.S. stocks have rallied, pushing the S&P 500 to a 4.4% total return for the year, including dividends, as of the close on Wednesday. But the good times probably won’t last, according to Rob Arnott, founder of the investment research firm Research Affiliates and co-manager of funds such as Pimco All Asset All Authority (ticker: PAUAX).A value-oriented contrarian, Arnott has long warned that U.S. stocks look pricey. And he’s especially concerned now that a handful of big tech stocks are carrying the market on their shoulders.“U.S. stocks have gotten frothy and expensive,” Arnott told Barron’s in an interview. “The FAANG stocks, in particular, are priced for perfection. If they don’t reinforce the notion that they’ll be 10 times as large a decade from now, then they’re overpriced and will perform badly.”The FAANGs refer to Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX), and Google’s parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Along with a few other big-tech stocks, including Microsoft (MSFT) and Chinese internet firms Alibaba Group Holding (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU), they have become a huge source of market concentration and power: Their total equity value tops $4.2 trillion, and they have been fueling the market’s gains.“The seven or eight largest companies on the planet are all tech darlings,” says Arnott. “Is that a diversified roster of top tier companies? Hardly.”Arnott points out that U.S. stocks trade at 30 times earnings, based on the cyclically adjusted price/earnings ratio (CAPE) from the last 10 years, a valuation measure developed by Nobel-winning economist Robert Shiller. The CAPE ratio only topped 30 once in history, just before the dot-com collapse, he says.Emerging markets, by contrast, look like a screaming buy. They trade at a CAPE ratio of 13. Investors worry that declining currencies and commodity prices will keep emerging markets depressed, and that the trade war between the U.S. and China will continue to be a drag on growth.But Arnott views those fears as overblown. “Will the trade war materially change the trajectory of half the world’s gross domestic product over the next 10 years?” he asks. “The answer is no.You cannot have a bargain in the absence of bad news that could get worse before it gets better. If you can accept that, then you have an opportunity to get some very good deals.”Granted, investors in Pimco All Asset All Authority haven’t seen great returns. The fund is down about 7% this year, and its 10-year annualized return of 5% trails 90% of mutual funds in the moderate-target-risk category, according to Morningstar.Arnott points out that most funds in the category are typically anchored to a 60/40 mix of stocks and bonds. All Authority aims to be different, holding what he calls “third-pillar” assets that can protect investors in a bear market and should do well in an inflationary environment: commodities, Treasury-inflation protected securities, and real-estate investment trusts. He also likes “stealth inflation fighters” such as emerging-market stocks and bonds, and high-yield U.S. junk bonds.Moreover, the fund is typically short the U.S. stock market, betting it will go down. “We actually have to love U.S. stocks in order to go above 0% in net U.S. stock exposure in All Authority,” he wrote in an email to Barron’s. Not surprisingly, he added, our returns “are in line with our home-base third pillar markets.”Those markets had an average return of 0.8% over the last five years. “That’s why our return lagged US stock-centric approaches—not because we’ve had an increasingly cautious view on U.S. equities,” he said.Still, it has been a painful slog for investors who have stuck with the fund while U.S. stocks have climbed, rising at a 14% annualized gain over the last decade, based on returns for the SPDR S&P 500 exchange-traded fund (SPY).“All Authority’s home base–away from mainstream stocks and bonds–will reliably lead to underperformance in a bull market,” Arnott tells Barron’s. “That’s what diversification does in a bull market.” At the end of what is now the longest bull market in history, he adds, “this is not a time to worry about the drag imposed by diversifying asset classes. “Indeed, Arnott sees a good chance that markets will start moving in his favor: He pegs the odds of a bear market breaking out in the U.S. in the near term at 40%. Investors might do well in a fund without much correlation to U.S. stocks in that scenario, though as he acknowledges, they may have to wait for their patience to be rewarded.“Do I have high confidence that the asset classes we focus on will beat U.S. stocks next year? No,” he says. “But I have high confidence they’ll win over a 10-year horizon.”Write to Daren Fonda at daren.fonda@barrons.com

Title: Hedge Funds Were Selling FAANG Stocks Before They Sank
Text: FAANG stocks have had one of their worst routs in recent months, with all of the them dipping into bear-market levels at some point–meaning share prices plunging 20% or more from the latest peak.Some hedge funds might have avoided part of that damage by selling the FAANGs early enough.In the third quarter, hedge funds sold over $34 billion in stocks–about 2% of their total assets, Jefferies strategist Steven DeSanctis writes in a Friday research report.It’s worth noting that the S&P 500 did not start dropping until Oct. 3; but hedge funds were already reducing weight in stocks throughout the third quarter in anticipation of higher risks and a trend change in the equity market.More noticeable was the sharp decline in their FAANG exposure. Hedge-fund managers reduced 14.6% of their FAANG holdings in the third quarter. Facebook (FB), whose shares are now 36.2% down from a July peak, saw hedge funds cut their holdings in the social network by 28%–a whopping $7.5 billion.Hedge funds were getting rid of FAANG stock before they slid. During the third quarter, while Facebook tumbled 16.7% and Netflix (NFLX) lost 6.0%, the other three FAANGs– Alphabet (GOOGL), Apple (AAPL), and Amazon.com (AMZN)–made gains. The FAANG stocks topped out at different times this summer, Barron’s noted.DeSanctis thinks hedge funds might be selling for another reason too: They were trying to raise more cash in preparation for next year’s redemption. Hedge-fund performance has been weak throughout 2018, even when compared with exchange-traded and mutual funds. Some managers might be anticipating more redemption from investors in 2019 and getting ready with their cash flow, writes DeSanctis.Whatever the reason, hedge funds’ shedding of FAANG stock has certainly contributed to the further turmoil for the group in October and November. In the fourth quarter so far through Thursday, all FAANGs were in negative territory, with losses ranging from 9.0% to 24.3%.“If this [hedge-fund] money comes back to the market, it potentially provides some fuel for a nice rally,” writes DeSanctis.Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

Title: 10 Stocks That Could Tank, According to Morgan Stanley
Text: Stock analysts issue more flattery than flak. For each 10 positive ratings of companies in the S&P 500 index, there is only a single negative one, according to a Barron’s screen of FactSet data. So thumbs-down reports tend to stand out.For example, Morgan Stanley on Thursday published a list of its favorite “secular growth stocks,” which the firm’s analysts reckon can “grow strongly independent of global economic conditions.”There are some predictable names, like Amazon.com (AMZN) and Netflix (NFLX), and some picks that are less universally adored, like the biotech firm Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Assurant (AIZ), which sells, among other things, extended warranties for smartphones. But a companion list of “secularly challenged stocks” was perhaps more eye-catching.Listen to a conversation between Jack Hough and Alex Eule about what to do with Facebook’s unloved stock in a recent episode of The Readback. You can sign up for the podcast in iTunes or wherever you listen to podcasts.That list includes stocks rated Underweight by Morgan Stanley’s analysts, where the price target is near or below the recent share price. Risk and reward for each are skewed unfavorably, with potential downside in a bearish scenario exceeding potential upside in a bullish one. And for each, the analyst’s negative thesis rests on more than fleeting problems—things like rising competition or deteriorating end markets. Among 25 stocks on the list, the 10 listed below had bear cases that implied at least 60% downside from recent levels.Two important caveats: First, bear cases aren’t what the firm sees as the likeliest outcome for each stock. Base cases are, and those point to the price targets listed below. Second, struggling companies can produce big gains on good news, as illustrated Thursday by one company on the list. Abercrombie & Fitch stock closed up 21% after its third-quarter report suggested a strong start to the holiday shopping season.So consider the following a think-twice-before-buying list, in one firm’s view, and not a list of stocks to bet against. The price targets listed are Morgan Stanley’s base case, not the bear case.Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $14Thursday’s closing price: $20.70Challenges include market share losses to fast-fashion, discount, and online retailers.Avis Budget Group (CAR)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $30Thursday’s closing price: $29.08Challenges include ride-hailing services, leverage, potential for decline in used car residual values.Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $13Thursday’s closing price: $12.78Challenges include rising competition from Wayfair,At Home, and mass merchants.EQT (EQT)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $12Thursday’s closing price: $18.80Challenges include high cost structure, risk to natural gas production growth.Fitbit (FIT)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $4Thursday’s closing price: $5.38Challenges include competition from Apple and Garmin, uncertainty over future product improvements.Hertz Global Holdings (HTZ)Morgan Stanley base case price target $15Thursday’s closing price: $18.65Challenges include ride-hailing services, leverage, potential for decline in used car residual values.Juniper Networks (JNPR)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $20Thursday’s closing price: $28.59Challenges include underinvestment versus peers in networking, and cybersecurity.MSG Networks (MSGN)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $23Thursday’s closing price: $27.58Challenges include rising sports rights costs, potential for subscriber erosion.Seaspan (SSW)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $5.50Thursday’s closing price: $9.65Challenges include leverage, expanding global fleet, trade friction.Tenneco (TEN)Morgan Stanley base case price target: $30Thursday’s closing price: $33.34Challenges include leverage, exposure to cyclical downturn in auto components, limited products for full-electric cars.Write to Jack Hough at jack.hough@barrons.com

Title: The Stock Market Keeps Forming a ‘Death Cross.’ What’s That?
Text: You’ve probably seen the word “death cross” a lot in the financial media lately. While the name itself sounds ominous enough, it’s important to understand what it is exactly, why people care about it—and why you shouldn’t panic when it happens.A death cross is a chart pattern that appears when a stock’s short-term moving average—meaning the average price over a certain time period—crosses below its long-term moving average. There is no fixed rule about what time frame to look at, but many define it as the crossover of the 50-day moving average and the 200-day moving average.A death cross is viewed by technical analysts as a signal that a major downturn is coming, as it suggests the short-term momentum in the underlying asset is slowing down enough and graduating into a long-term downtrend.To be sure, a death cross is usually not the earliest sign of a downtrend, but rather often confirms a pullback that’s been in place for a while. Investors concerned about bear markets often view the death cross as a timing signal to get out and lock in the gains before everything turns ugly. Hence, a death cross accompanied by high trading volume is considered especially significant, since that means people are starting to panic and sell.This year has seen no shortage of death crosses. A group of stocks, indexes, and asset classes have seen such a move. That incudes Facebook in April; gold in June; the Russell 2000on Nov. 13; Alphabeton Nov. 15; Netflix on Nov. 19; crude oil on Nov. 23; and the Nasdaq Composite on Nov. 26. Even the S&P 500came close to forming a death cross—twice.So does a death cross really bring about death? Not necessarily.First of all, a death cross is only so meaningful when both the short-term and long-term moving averages are declining. If the short-term line is falling but the long-term line is still going up, that’s not as concerning.Since 1928, the S&P 500 has experienced 12 “true” death crosses when both moving averages were going down, according to Bespoke Investment Group’s George Pearkes. The index declined 83% of the time in the month following those occurrences, with a median decline of 3.1%. But during the subsequent six months, stocks were actually positive 83% of the time, returning a median gain of 9.8%.“While a death cross doesn’t necessarily spell the death of secular gains for equities, they have historically been a relatively bad sign for near-term equity returns.” Pearkes wrote in a recent note.In fact, death crosses have become more common. Out of the 12 death crosses in the history of the S&P 500, four have occurred in this current bull market.“The fact that we haven’t seen a bear market following 4 separate instances of a death cross since 2010 is a good example of why ‘death’ might be a slight exaggeration!” Pearkes said.Indeed, investors who fled the market out of fear of the death cross missed sizable gains that came along later. Those who bought the dip gained handsomely in the following years.So a death cross might not be as fatal as it sounds. Instead, investors should treat it as just one of the alarming signs—among many others—they should watch for.Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

Title: Stocks to Watch: Amazon, GM, Campbell, Papa John’s
Netflix Chief Content Officer to Present at the UBS 46th Annual Global Media and Communications Conference
Option-trading opportunities on Adobe Systems, Alibaba, Micron, Netflix, and Tesla Motors
Match Group Partners with Syndio to ensure Pay Equity
Momo Reschedules Third Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call to December 6, 2018
Why eBay is betting on payments to help its turnaround
Text: EBay Inc. is hoping for a revival of sorts, and it’s betting that a more active role in payments might help spice up the platform.Payments were once deemed a boring area not worth the time or investment for e-commerce companies, but marketplaces are now taking control of this part of their business as a way to enhance the shopping experience for both buyers and sellers. Shoppers often leave their carts behind if the checkout process takes too long, and small merchants have no shortage of options when it comes to selling items online. EBay EBAY, +1.17%  executives believe a more simplified payments experience will make the platform more appealing on both sides.The company is in the early days of a move toward managed payments that will eventually relegate PayPal Holdings Inc. PYPL, +2.53% which was spun out of eBay in 2015, to a lesser role on the site. The e-commerce platform is following in the footsteps of online peers Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +4.86%  and Etsy Inc. ETSY, +4.76% both of which mix payments with the services they offer sellers. EBay expects that overall fees for sellers will come down under the new initiative.Don’t miss: EBay is learning from Spotify in its bid to make shopping more personalEarlier this fall, eBay began migrating a small portion of its volume from PayPal to its new managed-payments service, which is being done in partnership with European payment-processor Adyen N.V. ADYEN, +2.79% Most sellers are seeing a 25% savings on fees when the company is managing everything for them end-to-end, Alyssa Cutright, eBay’s vice president of global payments, told MarketWatch.When eBay announced the move to manage payments back in January, Chief Executive Devin Wenig said he expected the move would “capture significantly better economics while reducing overall selling costs.”The goal is for sellers to also be able to handle logistics more seamlessly, with just one contract required for both payments and selling, as well as a single company to contact with any issues. “Often sellers will call with questions on payments and we’ll have to say we don’t have information on that and that they have to contact PayPal,” Cutright said. “It’s hard when you don’t have the whole picture.”See also: Square expands business-lending program through eBay partnershipThe company also hopes to attract more buyers by accepting a variety of local payment methods, especially when it comes to regions where Visa Inc. V, +2.32%  and Mastercard Inc. MA, +4.37%  aren’t as prevalent.“You go into some markets and you see much more stored-value mobile or carrier-based payment options,” Cutright said. “We want to make sure that if there are buyers that we want to reach in any of these given markets, we allow them to pay in a manner that’s familiar.”PayPal also sees potential in adding more local payment methods and embarked on a global rollout of its “smart buttons” initiative in September. That technology looks at location and past habits to render relevant payments buttons for a given customer.EBay’s managed-payments system includes Apple Pay AAPL, +3.49%  as an additional checkout option, and Cutright said that 1 in 5 iOS shoppers on eBay have chosen to complete their purchases with that mobile wallet when it was listed on the platformManagement sees a $2 billion annual revenue opportunity and the potential for $500 million in incremental operating profit once the transition to managed payments is complete, which is expected to happen by the end of 2021. EBay’s operating agreement with PayPal expires in 2020, and the company is limited in how much volume it can move to the new system until then.Don’t miss: Square launches new product for merchants who won’t give up on terminalsAnalysts, too, now see payments as a catalyst that could help eBay’s stalled stock. Lowering costs for sellers is “a clear win,” D.A. Davidson’s Tom Forte told MarketWatch, while letting consumers pay with their preferred payment method instead of incentivizing them to use PayPal should benefit the platform, he reasoned.The initial transition to managed payments hasn’t come without hitches, however. Some sellers who opted in to the initial rollout have complained on eBay’s community forums that they saw their sales take a hit once they became part of the new system.“The elephant in the room is: loyal ebay customers really LOVE PayPal and TRUST PayPal,” wrote one, who cited “an immediate and drastic drop in sales” after switching over.Cutright admits that there has been a bit of consumer apprehension about the new payment system. The company has found that some buyers worry that eBay is sharing card details with sellers when PayPal isn’t listed as a checkout option, and the site has tweaked its messaging to clarify that card information remains secure.Though PayPal won’t run payments for the new eBay system, the e-commerce giant hopes to add the PayPal button as an option at checkout in 2019. Adding PayPal is “our absolute no. 1 priority that we are working on with urgency,” Cutright said.Read: PayPal sees encouraging growth from Venmo; stock surgesThe bumpy rollout is “a little concerning,” Wedbush analyst Ygal Arounian told MarketWatch, though he said that the transition is a long-term process. By virtue of the operating agreement with PayPal, eBay has to migrate volume to the new system gradually, which should give it time to work out the kinks, he argued.Advertising is another key element of the eBay turnaround story, according to Arounian. The company is making a bigger push into promoted listings.EBay shares have fallen 21% so far this year, while the S&P 500                           SPX, +1.09%                    has gained 2.5%.Emily Bary is a MarketWatch reporter based in New York.Join the conversation

Title: Mobile Apps Can Help Relieve Holiday Stress; App Usage on the Rise in Canada
Takes on the Shares of Salesforce, Aspen, Dick’s, and Under Armour
Text: These reports, excerpted and edited by Barron’s, were issued recently by investment and research firms. The reports are a sampling of analysts’ thinking; they should not be considered the views or recommendations of Barron’s. Some of the reports’ issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.Buy • Price $127.54 on Nov. 27 by R.W. BairdThe cloud-computing company reported a beat-and-raise third-quarter 2019 (ended in October) and provided an estimated initial fiscal 2020 (January) revenue guidance gain of 20% to 21%, year over year. (The consensus estimated gain was at 20%.)This positive forward guidance, along with CEO Mark Benioff’s comments around strong macro conditions in the Americas and Asia Pacific, should remove portions of a bear case weighing on an uncertain 2019.We have conviction at current levels and reiterate Salesforce as a top large-cap pick with a Buy rating. That said, we are lowering our price target to $165 to reflect recent pullbacks in software-as-a-service comparison-group valuations.Buy Price $80.05 on Nov. 27 by Canaccord GenuityIt’s time to step up. We are upgrading the shares of the process-optimization company to a Buy. Our struggle with Aspen has largely been tied to valuation—we could never get comfortable paying 30 times to 35 times forward free cash flow for mid-single digit growth. (The company provides its services to chemical, medical, oil-and-gas, and food-processing businesses, among others.)For better or worse, two things have changed our view of Aspen: First, the stock is down 33% from September highs, so that valuation is now a more reasonably estimated 24 times enterprise value/free cash flow on calendar 2019. And second, our confidence has increased in a reacceleration that should see it growing 10%-plus in the next couple of years.Stepping back, our experience has been that, in periods of market volatility, investors crowd into perceived havens, often defined by high visibility and margins.With 40%-plus free-cash-flow profits, five- to six-year term contracts, and a technical edge that demands customer loyalty—in the processing of fluid substances, rather than the assembling of, say, electronic parts—Aspen fits the “haven” bill.We see the stock at $100 again at some point in 2019.Buy Price $36.33 on Nov. 27 by CowenOverall, the gross margin; sales, general, and administrative expense, or SG&A; and capital expenditure commentary on the sports and outdoor gear retailer’s call suggest that its margin profile is stabilizing. Consider these numbers:1) Dick’s surpassed third-quarter 2018 expectations on improved expense control, which led to earnings per share of 39 cents, above our estimate of 37 cents and the consensus estimate of 26 cents.2) SG&A dollars were at -2.5%, year over year, on a per-store basis and -1.5% overall, driven by expense management.3) Third-quarter same-store sales, or SSS, had some bright spots as apparel momentum drove SSS up to mid-single digit gains for outdoor/athletic. Footwear, though, was flattish, due to a self-inflicted underinventoried position.4) Dick’s merchandise margin was up.5) Overall inventory was up 0.8%, but down -1.2% on a “shifted” or “for special occasions” basis. Levels are expected to rise by year end, as Dick’s reinvests in these “enthusiast” categories.Our rating and price target of $39 are unchanged.Equal Weight Price $22.22 on Nov. 26 by Morgan Stanley ResearchThe branded footwear and apparel developer, marketer, and retailer appeals especially to young and athletic men and women. It sells its merchandise under its own logos and others’.Under Armour will host its first investor day in three years on Dec. 12. We see a 40% chance that it outlines a credible five-year path. This could drive the stock 10% or higher, in our view, which options currently do not price in.The bull/bear debate on Under Armour among investors remains fierce, with bulls eyeing a 10%-plus five-year Ebit margin target. Consensus forecasts a 6% 2020 (two-year) Ebit margin, and we think the market expects a high-single digit five-year Ebit-margin target.We see three potential stock outcomes:Base Case: Stock moves up about 5%, and grinds higher as consensus estimates move slightly higher and the market gains more confidence. Likelihood: 5%.Bull Case: The stock moves up about 10%. Consensus estimates move significantly higher, forcing many shorts to cover. A compelling path to a double-digit Ebit margin—new products drive new long-only money into the name. Likelihood: 10%.Bear Case: Stock moves down 10%. Under Armour’s low-mid-single digit revenue compound annual growth rate guidance calls into question Under Armor’s ability to reignite the brand. Likelihood: 10%.Our target price—$22.22 at the time of this writing—is more than a dollar above the shares’ current price of $21.Email: editors@barrons.com

Title: Financialbuzz.com: Buzz on the Street Market News Recap Week Ending November 29th 2018
7 Companies That Do Everything Well
Salesforce Announces Salesforce Tower Chicago, Commits to Adding 1,000 New Local Jobs
Salesforce stock logs best day in 3½ years as analysts embrace confidence in growth
Text: Salesforce.com Inc. shares rallied for their strongest gain in more than three-and-a-half years Wednesday as analysts took a strong earnings report and outlook as a sign the customer-relations management software company may be insulated from a feared tech downturn.Salesforce CRM, +0.97%  shares surged 10.3% to close at $140.64 for their best one-day percentage gain since April 29, 2015, after third-quarter results and next year’s outlook topped what Wall Street analysts had estimated at the time.Salesforce shares were also Wednesday’s strongest performer on S&P 500 index SPX, +1.09%  which closed up 2.3%. Shares of software company Adobe Inc. ADBE, +1.74%  were Wednesday’s second-best performer on the S&P 500, with a 7.3% gain.Salesforce shares, which last week had experienced their worst day in nearly three years, popped above their 200-day moving average for the first time since Nov. 14. The stock price is still 12.8% off its all-time high of $161.19 set on Oct. 1, days after the company wrapped up its annual Dreamforce convention in San Francisco.Of the 43 analysts who cover Salesforce, 39 have buy or overweight ratings, four have hold ratings and no one has a sell or underweight rating. Of those, eight analysts raised their price targets and three lowered theirs, resulting in an average price target of $171.82, down from the average of $172.08 before earnings, according to FactSet data.Monness Crespi analyst Brian White said Salesforce’s conference call was “the most bullish we’ve heard this earnings season from a tech company,” while Canaccord analyst Richard Davis said Salesforce is key in digital transformation, or where companies adopt software-based solutions for business processes.“In order, Salesforce, ServiceNow NOW, +1.52% , Microsoft MSFT, +1.08% Workday WDAY, +2.32%  and Adobe ADBE, +1.74%  are leading that charge among public companies,” Davis said. “This is bad news for legacy vendors such as IBM IBM, +0.84% , SAP SAP, +1.55%  and Oracle ORCL, +2.19% and it’s why the first two have thrown an M&A equivalent of a ‘Hail Mary’ with big acquisitions they hope will be transformative.”Recently, IBM offered to buy Red Hat Inc. for $34 billion, while SAP said it would buy Utah-based software company Qualtrics for $8 billion.Read: Forecasts see no dark clouds on horizon for Salesforce, NutanixBTIG analyst Joel Fishbein said Salesforce’s outlook for fiscal 2020 was key in instilling confidence in investors.“The initiation of the company’s FY20 revenue outlook at $16B (at the high end of the range, 20-21% y/y growth) is encouraging and signals multiyear visibility at a time when investors are increasingly worried that this tech gravy train can’t go on forever,” Fishbein said.Both Cowen analyst J. Derrick Wood and Evercore ISI analyst Kirk Materne noted that perceived weakness going forward isn’t reflecting on fundamentals given that currency exchange will impose a $200 million headwind in the fourth quarter as opposed to a $130 million tailwind in the year-ago quarter, and that Salesforce had a huge fourth quarter last year, making comparisons difficult.“Importantly, the co. did not indicate the deceleration was due to any slowdown in the business and mgmt reiterated its bullish stance about the health of the demand environment and its pipeline heading into the end of the year,” Wood noted.Jefferies analyst John DiFucci observed: “What stuck out to us was the comment that CEOs in Europe appear to be more conservative and less optimistic than their counterparts in the U.S. and Asia,” DiFucci noted. “While nothing to be alarmed over given the strength in EMEA in recent quarters, we think this is worth monitoring for Salesforce and the overall software group.”Raymond James analyst Brian Peterson noted: “While shares aren’t immune from broader macro trends, large deal activity in F3Q was clearly better than feared, suggesting that CRM’s tailwinds are long-term in nature.”Among the minority of “hold” analysts, Needham analyst Scott Berg said: “While we remain Hold-rated on CRM shares, the company’s 3Q results and initial FY20 revenue guidance were markedly better than expectations and have us more constructive on the shares.”Pivotal Research Group analyst Brian Wieser referred to third-quarter results as “decent” and reinforced his “positive long-term view on the company” but kept his rating at hold and his price target at $140.For the fourth quarter, Salesforce said it expects adjusted earnings of 54 cents to 55 cents a share on revenue of $3.55 billion to $3.56 billion, and revenue of $15.9 billion to $16 billion for fiscal 2020.As a result, analysts lowered their forecasts to a consensus 55 cents a share from a previous 57 cents a share, and raised their revenue forecast to $3.56 billion from a previous $3.52 billion. For fiscal 2020, analysts raised the consensus to $15.96 billion from a previous $15.8 billion.Wallace Witkowski is a MarketWatch news editor in San Francisco. Follow him on Twitter @wmwitkowski.Join the conversation

Title: The Dow Surges 618 Points as the Fed Loosens Up
Text: Relief Surge. All three major indexes rose sharply on Wednesday as Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicates the interest rates are “just below” the neutral rates that neither aid nor hinder economic growth. Hopes were raised that there might be a potential trade truce between the U.S. and China. In today’s After the Bell, we……wonder whether we’ll see any progress in trade before the year-end;…explain why companies have been pulling back from spending plans despite record-high earnings;… and observe a software firm’s stock surge today.Fed Still MattersThe dovish tone from Fed Chair Jerome Powell today might have eased the nerve of some investors who worry the central bank might be tightening too much.The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 617.70 points, or 2.5%, to 25,366.43, while the S&P 500 rose 61.61 points, or 2.3%, to 2743.78 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 208.89 points, or 3.0%, to 7291.59.Powell said on Wednesday that rates are “just below” neutral–that is, neither speeding up nor slowing down economic growth, hinting that the Fed lighten up next year. “Given signs of a global slowdown and extreme market volatility over the past few months, investors will be keen for a sense of the Fed’s hiking plans for next year,” writes Jasper Lawler of London Capital Group on Wednesday.Fed policy is not the only uncertainty in the market, as trade headlines from the White House has also been contradicting ahead of the G20 meeting later this week, which is viewed as “the last opportunity this year to move trade talks forward,” according to Lawler.Kristina Hooper, a strategist at Invesco, is not optimistic about the outcome of the G20 meeting. President Donald Trump insisted on new tariff threats just ahead of the meeting, writes Hooper, and Chinese President Xi Jinping may not be under pressure to make concessions. “After all, China has the ability to play a long game and the U.S. doesn’t,” she writes on Wednesday.Hooper points out that China has many more weapons in its arsenal in a trade war, including depreciating the currency, launching fiscal stimuli, lowering taxes and interest rates increasing subsidies, and ending the purchasing of U.S. Treasuries, to name a few.Uncertainty on the trade dispute has been hindering companies from spending more. Corporations have pulled back on expenditures even as the economy is expanding at one of its fastest paces of the cycle.According to data released on Wednesday by the Commerce Department, business spending on equipment in the third quarter has registered the weakest growth since the fourth quarter of 2016, and contributed only 0.2 percentage points to the GDP’s 3.5% growth. During the same quarter last year, the contribution was 0.6 percentage points out of 2.8% GDP growth.“The trade dispute has been difficult to navigate for U.S. corporations, and many have opted to put future expansions on hold until there is more clarity on the tangible and intangible effects of tariffs on demand and profits,” writes John Lynch of LPL Financial on Wednesday.Crude oil prices are now down more than 30% from the October peak, hurting the profit margins of energy companies and their spending plans.But Lynch thinks the slowdown of business spending is only temporary and things will start picking up.“Once U.S. businesses have clarity on trade, they may be able to focus more on boosting growth and productivity, which may fuel the next leg of the U.S. economic expansion.” writes Lynch.The Hot StockSalesforce.com (CRM) shot to the top of the S&P 500 Wednesday, bolstered by upbeat third-quarter earnings.Salesforce.com gained $13.10, or 10.3%, to $140.64.The software firm earned 61 cents a share on revenue of $3.39 billion. Analysts were looking for EPS of 50 cents on revenue of $3.37 billion. For the full year, it sees EPS of $2.60 to $2.61, on revenue of $13.23 billion to $13.24 billion.Macquarie’s Sarah Hindlian reiterated an Outperform rating and $174 price target on Salesforce.com, writing that the quarter was “solid,” while the conference call “suggested a positive tone bringing macro relief.”Year to date, Salesforce.com is up 37.8%The Biggest LoserTiffany (TIF) slunk to the bottom of the index, following its third-quarter earnings.Shares of the storied jeweler lost $12.41, or 11.8%, to $92.54.Tiffany said it earned 77 cents a share, matching analysts’ estimates, on revenue of $1.01 billion, below the $1.05 billion consensus. Comparable sales rose 3%, less than the 6.2% the Street was expecting. For the full year, the company sees EPS of $4.65 to $4.80, below the $4.83 analysts are modeling for.Still, CFRA’s Camilla Yanushevsky reiterated a Buy rating and $124 price target on Tiffany, writing that while she understands “concerns with [the quarter’s] sales miss, we attribute it to lower spending by Chinese tourists, which, in our view, is a cyclical trend, as sales by the domestic Chinese were strong. Long term, we are encouraged by progress CEO Alessandro Bogliolo has made to re-brand Tiffany to resonate with millennials.”Year to date, Tiffany is down 11%.–Teresa RivasWrite to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com

Title: Salesforce Grants Equity Awards to Rebel Employees Under Its Inducement Equity Incentive Plan
This chart shows a good sign for tech stocks, but the bear is ready to pounce
Text: After President Trump’s tweet about a potential 10% tariff on iPhone imports from China, investors’ heightened attention to technology stocks moved a notch higher.Becky Quick of CNBC was in tune with investor concerns, as shown in this segment, but it was my answer to the spot-on question from Andrew Ross Sorkin on tech stocks that has generated the most emails. At a time when gurus’ calls are on both bullish and bearish sides, many investors found some clarity in “Here’s how to tell if stocks will enter a bear market or rise to new highs.”Important events are ahead. Let’s update the situation with the help of a chart.Please click here for an annotated chart of Nasdaq 100 ETF QQQ, +1.75% I chose the chart of this ETF over the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.13% the S&P 500 ETF SPY, +1.32% and the small-cap ETF IWM, +0.96% because of dominance of tech stocks in the Nasdaq 100. The four largest components in the Nasdaq 100 are Apple AAPL, +3.49% Amazon AMZN, +4.86% Microsoft MSFT, +1.08% and Google GOOG, +1.10%GOOGL, +0.60% Please note the following:• The chart shows a move above the trend line. This is positive.• The chart shows a very short-term bottoming pattern. This is positive.• The chart shows RSI (relative strength index) divergence. In plain English, this means that although the price fell below a prior low, RSI did not go as low. This is a mild positive.• As the chart shows, the overall pattern of RSI is positive.• The low came on somewhat heavier volume. This is mildly positive. However, this is a low conviction point; a significantly higher volume would have increased the probability of this being a bottom.• As the chart shows, the rally is on low volume. This is negative.• Positive earnings from Salesforce CRM, +0.97% and Nutanix NTNX, +0.56% are creating positive sentiment.• Smart-money flows in semiconductor stocks such as Applied Materials AMAT, +2.84% and Micron Technology MU, +3.81%  have turned to neutral from negative. Smart-money flows have been positive in Intel INTC, +1.66% through most of the tech decline; interestingly, Intel has held up well during this period. Smart-money flows turned positive in AMD AMD, +11.31% at the depth of the selloff. You already know from my writings over the years that smart-money flows have a great track record. The cherry on top is that smart-money flows were negative in Nvidia NVDA, +4.04% when the stock was trading around $290, momo (momentum) crowd flows were positive and it was the darling of tech investors. Smart-money flows stayed consistently negative on Nvidia, and ultimately the stock fell to as low as $133. Please see “The poster child of bull-market excess just dimmed the prospects of the broader stock market” to see how money flows provide you with an edge.• For the medium term, the bear is ready to pounce on some high-flying tech stocks. Popular high-flying tech stocks can be cut by 50% or more from their highs, as explained here.Ask Arora: Nigam Arora answers your questions about investing in stocks, ETFs, bonds, gold and silver, oil and currencies. Have a question? Send it to Nigam Arora.There are times to have high conviction because the data support it. Over the years, you have seen my calls on stocks ranging from sell everything or hedge in 2007, to go aggressively short in 2008 and then back up the truck and buy in 2009. You have also seen my calls to sell gold at $1,904 an ounce and silver at $50 an ounce, both of which turned out to be the tops.The data do not support high conviction in the medium term at this time. In the short term, it all comes down to the Federal Reserve’s policy and the result of President Trump’s meeting with China’s President Xi, as described here.For market timing, I follow the ZYX Asset Allocation Model, which has inputs in 10 categories. Please click here to see the 10 categories.Disclosure: Subscribers to The Arora Report may have positions in the securities mentioned in this article or may take positions at any time. Nigam Arora is an investor, engineer and nuclear physicist by background who has founded two Inc. 500 fastest-growing companies. He is the founder of The Arora Report, which publishes four newsletters. Nigam can be reached at Nigam@TheAroraReport.com.Nigam Arora is an engineer, nuclear physicist, author, and entrepreneur and the founder of two Inc. 500 fastest growing companies. He is also the developer of the ZYX Change Method to profit from change by investing. The premise is that most money is made by predicting change before the crowd. Arora is the chief investment officer at The Arora Report and the editor of four newsletters that track the ZYX Change Method. Nigam can be reached at Nigam@TheAroraReport.comJoin the conversation

Title: Salesforce Research Reveals Shoppers Go Online Early, Go Mobile and Go Social This Holiday Season
Thinking about buying stock in Aurora Cannabis Inc, Sphere 3D Corp, Arsanis, salesforce or Tilray Inc.?
Stocks to Watch: Amazon, GM, Campbell, Papa John’s
Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority Modernizes Regional Travel with Unified Payment System Powered by Salesforce
Michaels Expands with Salesforce to Create Personalization at Every Touchpoint
Forecasts see no dark clouds on horizon for Salesforce, Nutanix
Text: Investors jittery about the murky forecasts from several tech companies this quarter were pleased Tuesday that any references to clouds referred only to products, and not the outlooks for software firms Salesforce.com Inc. and Nutanix Inc.Both companies reported results that beat analysts’ expectations, sending their shares soaring in after-hours trading. The stock of Salesforce CRM, +0.97%  climbed nearly 9% after hours and was up that amount premarket Wednesday, after the customer-relationship management software firm reported a better-than-expected fiscal third quarter and a slightly better revenue outlook for fiscal 2019 and fiscal 2020. Nutanix NTNX, +0.56%  also jumped almost 9% in extended trading after posting an encouraging outlook. That stock was also up 9% premarket Wednesday.In conference calls with analysts, both companies were asked about their view of the macro economic environment.“I continue to see strong growth because I’ve seen so much investment this year. It’s going to pay out for these companies going forward,” Salesforce Co-Chief Executive Marc Benioff said. “So I see still several years ahead of good, solid growth for the economy, and where that gets tempered — I think I’ve mentioned this before — is when I talk to European CEOs, they tend to be more conservative.”However, there have been a smattering of CEOs in the U.S. who have said they are seeing a slowdown among their customers, especially in the semiconductor and semi equipment arena, a key underpinning of technology.Duston Williams, chief financial officer of Nutanix Inc. NTNX, +0.56%NTNX, +0.56% a developer of hybrid cloud software, echoed those thoughts. “We haven’t seen any slowdown in our business anyway,” he said. “Now, we’re not a $20 billion company that would have insight into everything. But certainly within our realm anyway, we’ve seen really no signs of that.”Shares of both Salesforce and Nutanix have declined in the past few weeks, with Salesforce off 23% since peaking in late September, “a victim of the selloff in popular high-growth technology,” wrote Steve Koenig, a Wedbush Securities analyst, in a recent note.Investors have been nervous about a slowdown as a potential impact from the Trump administration’s tariffs on tech products made or assembled in China, which includes some products in data-center hardware. In recent years, the build-out of more data centers across the world — both by companies for their own use and to rent out for cloud computing — has been one of the strongest growth engines in tech. Nutanix CEO Dheeraj Pandey told analysts that customers were both expanding workloads and continuing to modernize and create cloud-like experiences in their own data centers.Salesforce executives also pointed out that its fiscal-fourth-quarter revenue outlook was staying the same because of expected currency fluctuations, an issue brought up by a number of other companies, including Cisco Systems Inc.       CSCO, +1.82%Whether or not the outlook stays bright for the cloud companies is a big question going forward, but for now investors can relax. Combined with the strong results of the cloud infrastructure businesses of both Microsoft Corp.MSFT, +1.08%           and Amazon.com Inc.              AMZN, +4.86%          this quarter, cloud-related companies could be a safe haven from any impending storms, at least for now.Want this type of analysis sent to your inbox? Subscribe to MarketWatch's free MarketWatch First Takes newsletter. Sign up here.Therese Poletti is a senior columnist for MarketWatch in San Francisco. Follow her on Twitter @tpoletti.Join the conversation

Title: These stocks are in bear territory, but analysts expect them to roar back
Text: In any market, at any time, there are stocks whose values are down significantly. But during a market correction, there will be more of those, and you may find opportunities to scoop up bargains for extra profits when the broader market rebounds.In mid-October, data provided by FactSet showed that exactly half of the stocks included in the S&P 500 Index were down at least 20% from their all-time highs. With the market pulling back since then, it might be interesting to use more recent data to see which ones have declined the most from their 52-week highs.A bear market for an index or an individual stock is usually defined as a 20%-plus decline. At about 11:10 a.m. ET on Nov. 26, 206 stocks among the S&P 500 were down at least 20% from their 52-week highs. That’s a huge list, but it might be of interest to see which of the companies in bear territory are favored the most among Wall Street analysts, whose research is used by their broker colleagues to help push stock purchases.The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.13%  fell 10% from its intraday high on Oct. 3 through its intraday low on Nov. 23. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.09%  was down 10.5% from its intraday high on Sept. 21 through its intraday low on Nov. 23. Both benchmark indices had suffered corrections earlier in 2018. The Dow ended on Nov. 23 down 1.8% for the year, while the S&P 500 was down 1.5%.The Dow was last in a bear market heading to the post-crisis low on March 9, 2009. But even though the financial media generally agree that the bull market has continued from that date, the S&P 500 on an intraday basis was in a bear market when it fell 20.2% from an intraday high on July 1, 2011, through its intraday low on Oct. 4, 2011, according to data supplied by FactSet.Starting with the 206 S&P 500 stocks in bear territory (from 52-week highs) through 11:10 a.m. ET on Nov. 26, we have narrowed the list to 22 companies that are covered by at least 10 analysts, with at least 80% of the analysts rating the shares a “buy” or equivalent, according to FactSet.Here they are, ranked by the percentage of buy ratings:Don’t miss: Here’s how to easily reduce your investment risk just at the right timeCreate an email alert for Philip van Doorn’s Deep Dive columns here.Philip van Doorn covers various investment and industry topics. He has previously worked as a senior analyst at TheStreet.com. He also has experience in community banking and as a credit analyst at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.Join the conversation

Title: Backlog and Revenue Growth Power Salesforce Results
Salesforce Lifts the Cloud
Salesforce’s stock surges after earnings beat, fiscal 2020 revenue outlook
Text: Salesforce.com Inc. shares rallied in the extended session Tuesday after the customer-relations management software company’s quarterly results and revenue outlook for next year topped Wall Street estimates.Salesforce CRM, +0.97%  shares rose 7.4% after hours, following an initial 3% dip as the earnings report was released. Shares advanced 0.9% to close the regular session at $127.54 Tuesday, compared with a 0.3% rise in the S&P 500 index SPX, +1.09% and a less than 0.1% uptick in the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.51%For the fourth quarter, Salesforce said it expects adjusted earnings of 54 cents to 55 cents a share on revenue of $3.55 billion to $3.56 billion, while analysts forecast 57 cents a share on revenue of $3.52 billion.The company forecast adjusted earnings of $2.60 to $2.61 a share on revenue of $13.23 billion to $13.24 billion for fiscal 2019, and revenue of $15.9 billion to $16 billion for fiscal 2020. Analysts expect earnings of $2.51 a share on revenue of $13.17 billion for fiscal 2019, and revenue of $15.8 billion for fiscal 2020.“The company provided its initial guidance for FY20 of +20-21% vs. expectations in the 18-20%, which should help quell any concerns about a softening demand environment,” said Evercore ISI analyst Kirk Materne in a note. Materne has a outperform rating and a target price of $170.On the conference call Tuesday, Salesforce Co-Chief Executive and Chairman Marc Benioff backed up the company’s outlook, saying he doesn’t expect the economy to take a downturn or slip into recession, as some fear.“I consider to see strong growth because I’ve seen so much investment this year that’s going to pay out for these companies going forward,” Benioff said. “So, I see still several years ahead of good, solid growth for the economy.”Read: Software stocks experience worst selloff in nearly 3 years as tech continues to get beaten upThe San Francisco-based company reported third-quarter net income of $105 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $107 million, or 14 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings, however, were 61 cents a share.Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated earnings of 50 cents a share, while Salesforce had forecast 49 cents to 50 cents a share. Estimize, a software platform that uses crowdsourcing from hedge-fund executives, brokerages, buy-side analysts and others, called for earnings of 55 cents a share.Revenue rose to $3.39 billion from $2.70 billion in the year-ago quarter. Wall Street expected revenue of $3.37 billion from Salesforce, according to analysts polled by FactSet, while the company had predicted revenue of $3.36 billion to $3.37 billion. Estimize expected revenue of $3.39 billion.Billings for the quarter rose nearly 28% from a year ago to $2.89 billion, compared with the analyst consensus of $2.68 billion.Of the 42 analysts who cover Salesforce, 38 have buy or overweight ratings, four have hold ratings and no one has a sell or underweight rating, with an average price target of $172.08.Wallace Witkowski is a MarketWatch news editor in San Francisco. Follow him on Twitter @wmwitkowski.Join the conversation

Title: Salesforce Stock, Already Up 25% for 2018, Moves Higher on Strong Earnings
Text: Salesforce.com (CRM) has made no secret of its goal of reaching $23 billion in sales by fiscal 2022.On Tuesday, it reported better-than-expected third-quarter results and offered full-year guidance that indicates its long-term goals are proceeding as planned.The San Francisco-based enterprise-software company reported adjusted earnings of 61 cents per share and a 26% jump in revenue to $3.39 billion, besting Wall Street estimates and sending its stock up sharply.It also raised revenue guidance for fiscal 2019 to $13.23 billion–$13.24 billion, and $15.9 billion–$16 billion for fiscal year 2020. If Salesforce achieves top-end growth in fiscal 2020, it would be the first enterprise-software company to reach $16 billion in revenue.While fourth-quarter earnings guidance was slightly below analyst estimates of 57 cents per share, initially pushing Salesforce shares down 3% after the close, the stock rebounded and is now up more than 7% to $136.55 in after-hours trading. Shares had closed Tuesday at $127.54, up 25% this year, despite a recent drubbing of tech stocks.As expected, subscription and support sales led the way in third-quarter revenue, at $3.17 billion, up 26% year over year. Salesforce said sales are benefiting as well from its $6.5 billion acquisition of business-software company MuleSoft this year.At the same time, Salesforce has invested in artificial intelligence and analytics tools to help corporate customers better parse their data.“What we are seeing is that every company is going through digital transformation. No company is immune,” Salesforce co-CEO Keith Block told Barron’s, citing particularly strong customer growth in financial services, health care, and public sectors.Added Salesforce Chief Financial Officer Mark Hawkins: “This is what durable growth looks like.”Write to Jon Swartz at jonathan.swartz@dowjones.com

Title: Salesforce Announces Record Third Quarter Fiscal 2019 Results
Salesforce earnings: Can a strong quarter overcome ‘bear goggles’?
Text: Salesforce.com Inc. is expected to show strong results from its Dreamforce quarter Tuesday, but after a storm of poor tech forecasts put “bear goggles” on investors, the cloud-software company’s outlook will be the most closely watched disclosure.Salesforce CRM, +0.97%  is scheduled to report earnings after the market closes Tuesday. Analysts largely report healthy channel checks following Salesforce’s bullish annual Dreamforce conference in September, where the company revealed a Siri-enabled Einstein product following its announcement of a new enterprise partnership with Apple Inc.AAPL, +3.49% . Salesforce’s Einstein uses artificial intelligence to provide predictions and recommendations based on a company’s business processes and customer data, and faces competition from rival Microsoft Corp.MSFT, +1.08%Most analysts agreed that Salesforce shouldn’t have trouble with meeting or beating third-quarter expectations, but the fourth quarter is going to be much tougher. Salesforce’s billings outlook will be under pressure given last year’s big fourth quarter.Cowen analyst J. Derrick Wood, who has an outperform rating and a $180 price target, said investors have been concerned “for several months now” about the tough comparison that Salesforce faces in the fourth quarter.Salesforce is expected to post fourth-quarter billings of $6.81 billion, an increase of 22.6% from a year ago, according to FactSet.Monness Crespi analyst Brian White expects that no matter what Salesforce forecasts, the recent downward momentum on tech stocks may win out over fundamentals.“Although Salesforce gave off bullish vibes at Dreamforce in late September and we believe the company is positioned better than ever in the SaaS world, the market has grown more treacherous since then and the bar raised on what constitutes a strong quarter,” White, who has a buy rating and a $170 target price, said.“Given the unforgiving tech tape that we find ourselves in at the moment, the market is now wearing ‘bear goggles’ and searching for any excuse to go negative on a company.”Earnings: Of the 37 analysts surveyed by FactSet, Salesforce on average is expected to post adjusted earnings of 50 cents a share, down from the 53 cents a share expected at the beginning of the quarter. Salesforce forecast 49 cents to 50 cents a share. Estimize, a software platform that uses crowdsourcing from hedge-fund executives, brokerages, buy-side analysts and others, calls for earnings of 55 cents a share.Revenue: Wall Street expects revenue of $3.37 billion from Salesforce, according to 34 analysts polled by FactSet. Salesforce predicted revenue of $3.36 billion to $3.37 billion. Estimize expects revenue of $3.39 billion.Stock movement: Following Salesforce’s earnings report in late August, shares have fallen 18.3% as of Monday’s close, compared with an 8.3% decline in the S&P 500 index  SPX, +1.09%    and a 12.7% drop in the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index  COMP, +1.51%  over the same period. Recently, software stocks and Salesforce shares had their worst day in nearly three years in Nov. 19’s tech selloff.What analysts are saying: Of the 42 analysts who cover Salesforce, 38 have buy or overweight ratings, four have hold ratings and no one has a sell or underweight rating, with an average price target of $172.08.Jefferies analyst John DiFucci, who has a buy rating and a $189 price target, said Salesforce hitting the consensus for its fourth-quarter billing outlook is “certainly achievable.”“However, we note that CRM could guide below expectations, which it sometimes does (and tends to subsequently beat) due to what we view as a conservative approach to guidance,” DiFucci noted. “Regardless, we believe that the pipeline is robust, though the 4Q compare is relatively difficult after several years of strong finishes to the year.”Instinet analyst Christopher Eberle, who has a buy rating and a $181 target price, reminded investors that Salesforce will only be providing guidance for billings going forward, or expected revenue over the next 12 months, which he views as “an improved metric, as it reflects unbilled expected revenue, compared with unearned revenue, which only reflected billed business.”Wallace Witkowski is a MarketWatch news editor in San Francisco. Follow him on Twitter @wmwitkowski.Join the conversation

Title: Salesforce Investors Are Looking for Guidance
SINA Reports Third Quarter 2018 Unaudited Financial Results
The Increasing Use of Smart Devices is Driving the Global Mobile Payment Market Growth

Text: (Updated with market close information.)Whether you’re a fund manager or the president of the United States, a December stock rally is a wonderful thing. Many money managers have incentives tied to “locking in gains” before the end of the year, and of course President Trump wants all the bragging rights he can get.The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.13%  rose 288 points (1.1%) on Monday, while the S&P 500 SPX, +1.09%  also added 1.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.51%  was up 1.5% after Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to get serious about trade negotiations. Following a dinner Saturday night in Buenos Aires during the G-20 gathering, the U.S. agreed not to impose 25% tariffs on $200 billion in annual imports from China in January. This opens a 90-day window for a trade agreement.Read: Asia-Pacific stocks jump on U.S.-China trade truceTrump also said China had agreed to “reduce and remove tariffs on cars coming into China from the U.S.”Stocks were also helped by a 4.2% increase in West Texas Intermediate crude CLF9, +1.00% following an agreement between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman to cut production.Among the 30 components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, all but eight were up on Monday:You can click the tickers for more on each company, including news, profiles, price ratios, ratings and financials.Here are the 10 best-performing S&P 500 stocks on Monday:And here are the 10 best performers among the Nasdaq 100    NDX, +1.63%   :Don’t miss: Utility stocks have beaten the S&P 500 in two months of turbulence and in the long runCreate an email alert for Philip van Doorn’s Deep Dive columns here.Want news about Asia delivered to your inbox?
